(4)  Provide a certificate of insurance or other valid proof of general liability insurance in an amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence which shall remain in effect at all times while engaged in the permitted activity; 
(5)  Pay a permit fee according to the following table: 
Type of Applicant Permit Fee Permit Period Seasonal fireworks retailer $100.00 per location Automatically expires 30 calendar days after the effective date Permanent retailer with ancillary fireworks sales N/R Automatically expires 30 calendar days after the effective date  
In the event that an applicant wishes to operate more than one geographical location within the city, each location must have a separate permit and each permit is subject to the applicable permit fee; 
(6)  Comply with all aspects of applicable provisions of KRS Chapter 227, the International Building Code with Kentucky Amendments (adopted edition), NFPA 1124 (National Fire Protection Association) and the Mayfield Code of Ordinances, including obtaining a certificate of occupancy; 
(7)  Not allow any person under 18 years of age to sell consumer fireworks; 
(8)  Not give, offer for sale, or sell any consumer fireworks to any person under 18 years of age; and 
(9)  Not offer for sale, expose for sale, or sell consumer fireworks except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(10)  Display a readable version of the city fireworks ordinance within easy view of customers. 
(Ord. No. 7-12, § 4, 4-9-12; Ord. No. 27-16, § 4, 11-14-16) 
Sec. 6-25. - Display of permit. 
    A valid retail fireworks permit must be prominently displayed at each location and at all times during the hours of operation. The chief of the fire department or his designee may revoke or suspend any retail fireworks permit of any site which is in violation of this chapter, KRS Chapter 227 or the Code of Ordinances of the city or any other provisions of the Code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 7-12, § 5, 4-9-12; Ord. No. 27-16, § 5, 11-14-16) 
Sec. 6-26. - Ancillary fireworks retailers. 
    Ancillary fireworks retailers shall: 
(1)  Comply with all aspects of the applicable provisions of KRS Chapter 227, the International Building Code with Kentucky Amendments (adopted edition), NFPA 1124 (National Fire Protection Association) and the Code of Ordinances of the city, including but not limited to, any requirement for a certificate of occupancy in the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(2)  Not give, offer for sale, or sell any consumer fireworks to any person under 18 years of age; 
(3)  Not offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail or wholesale, or keep with intent to sell any consumer fireworks other than those described in KRS 227.702(1); 
(4)  Possess an occupational business license from the city in accordance with the Code of the city; and 
(5)  Maintain a certificate of insurance or other valid proof of general liability insurance in an amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 7-12, § 6, 4-9-12; Ord. No. 27-16, § 6, 11-14-16) 
Sec. 6-27. - Hours permitted for fireworks use within city limits. 
    Fireworks can be used within the city limits July 1 through 5, between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. only. Other than these dates and times, it is unlawful to explode, fire, shoot, or set off fireworks inside the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 27-16, § 7, 11-14-16) 
Sec. 6-28. - Criminal penalties. 
    Any person convicted of violating this article of the city shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $1,000.00, or confined in the county jail for not more than 30 days, or both. Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 7-12, § 7, 4-9-12; Ord. No. 27-16, § 8, 11-14-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 27-16, § 8, adopted Nov. 14, 2016, renumbered former § 6-27 as § 6-28. 
Chapter 7 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Food and food establishments, KRS 217.005 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Nuisances generally-Prohibited; enumeration. 
    A nuisance is anything whatsoever that is dangerous to health; whatever renders the ground, water, air or food a hazard or causes injury to health. The following specific acts, conditions and things, among others, are each hereby prohibited and made unlawful, and as such, may be abated; and any person guilty of causing or permitting or suffering any such nuisance to exist upon any premises or in any building occupied or controlled by such person, either as owner or tenant, or in any street, alley, sidewalk or gutter immediately adjacent to such premises, is liable upon conviction to punishment as provided in section 1-8: 
(1)  All cellars, vaults, drains, pools, cesspools, privies, sewers, yards, ground or premises which have from any cause become foul, nauseous or offensive, or injurious to health, or unpleasant to adjacent residents, or to persons passing by. 
(2)  All carcasses, decaying fish, fowl or vegetables, all deposits of manure or other unwholesome substances of any kind or description whatever, and all filthy or offensive water or slops in any private yard or premises, or when thrown or conducted into or upon any street, alley, public ground, or any enclosure so as to be unwholesome or offensive, or liable to become unwholesome or offensive. 
(3)  All markets, cellars, stores or other buildings or stores or places which are not kept clean and free from filthy or unwholesome substances that are offensive, or liable to cause disease. 
(4)  Depositing trash rubbish, filth or any foul, offensive, nauseous or injurious substances upon the sidewalk, street, alley, public thoroughfare, or any other public place. 
(5)  Sweeping or depositing any paper, trash or rubbish into any drain or gutter. 
(6)  Dry sweeping of sidewalks within the business districts between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., and on Saturdays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(7)  The burning of any hair, rubber, rags, or other substances of any kind which may cause or produce an offensive smell, smoke or odor capable of annoying persons living in the vicinity, or persons passing on any public thoroughfare in the city. 
(8)  The throwing from any opening in or carrying from any dwelling or place of abode, any night soil, feces, or filthy or unclean water upon an alley street, sidewalk or into any adjoining property. 
(9)  To permit or allow any weeds, filth or rubbish of any kind to remain on any vacant lot or sidewalk adjacent to any premises owned or controlled by such person, or in the street to the middle thereof, adjacent to any premises owned or controlled by any person, or upon any alley to the middle thereof, that may be adjacent to any lot owned or controlled by any person. 
(10)  The failure of the owner or possessor of any animal which may die, or any person causing the death of any animal, or the owner of any premises on which a dead animal is found, to have the carcass of the same removed from the city within 12 hours after the death of said animal. 
(11)  The conducting into any alley, street, or gutter of the waste water from the sink, tank, bath or wash race, or any source of water supply that produces any pools or stagnant water in said alleys, streets, or gutters, or upon the property of another. 
(12)  Any article or substance placed upon any street, sidewalk, alley, drain or public ground, except such as are permitted by the ordinances of the city, so as to obstruct the same; the throwing of glass, tin, queensware, crockery or other rubbish into or upon the sidewalks, streets, alleys, public thoroughfares, commons, drains or gutters. 
(13)  Any nauseous, foul or putrid liquors or substances or any liquor or substances likely to be nauseous, offensive or putrid, discharged, placed, thrown or conducted into or upon the streets, alleys, public grounds or commons; and the wrongful casting, throwing or depositing of any filth, substance or thing into any private well or cistern. 
(14)  Any act done or suffered within the city that interferes with the enjoyment of any member of the community, or any person who may be therein, of such person's rights to be free from foul, noxious, offensive or unpleasant odors and vapors, and to breathe fresh air and to be free from the sight of foul or offensive objects and substances. 
(15)  Medicine of any character delivered as samples in any manner whatever, except when handed to some adult. 
(16)  Live animals kept in any manner from which offensive odors shall arise, or kept in any place where the ground is not dry or can be adequately drained. 
(17)  Any business of any nature whatever, conducted or operated in such a manner that offensive or nauseous odors shall arise or be given off. 
(18)  Any carpets, rugs, mattresses, curtains, bedding, tapestry, cleaned, shaken or beaten in such a manner as to cause the lint, dust, dirt or other substance to enter the air over the street or other thoroughfares or property of others. 
(19)  Any building or part thereof which is overcrowded or not provided with adequate means of ingress or egress, or contains garbage, ashes, refuse or rubbish of whatever kind, or is not sufficiently ventilated, sewered, drained, lighted or cleaned. 
(20)  The placing or maintaining of any obstruction of any kind in any watercourse of the city so as to impede the following of water therein. 
(21)  The doing of any act which shall tend to pollute or contaminate the water supply of the city. 
(22)  Any room or dwelling which shall be leased, let or rented for human occupancy, and which room or dwelling, or any part hereof, is not sufficiently lighted or ventilated and provided with water and kept in a clean and sanitary condition, or in any part of which the ventilation, light or sewerage is in any manner dangerous, insufficient or prejudicial to life, or which shall not be provided with adequate and properly constructed water closets. 
(23)  Any well or cistern in water is of an impure or unwholesome nature. 
(24)  Any well or cistern in which an analysis shows that the water is of an impure or unwholesome nature. 
(25)  The outside storage, display, and sale of household appliances or furnishings other than in an enclosed, secure building. 
(26)  The keeping of an un-licenced, inoperative, or dilapidated vehicle except in a licensed junk yard, temporarily on the premises of a licensed repair establishment while awaiting repair for a period not to exceed 30 days, or in an enclosed, secure structure. 
(27)  The storage of any vehicle in the public right-of-way, regardless of operational status, for more than a 48-hour period. 
(28)  The storage or parking of vehicles within 50 ft of the back of curb or edge of pavement, regardless of operational status of the vehicle, without movement of said vehicle every 180 days, except in a licensed junk yard, or in an enclosed, secure structure. 
(29)  Any house containing broken windows or doors or other means of ingress that are not securable and that constitute easy entrance into a place where illegal activity may occur, including drug trade and abuse. 
(Ord. of 1-16-28, § 1; Ord. No. 15-97, § 2, 1-12-98; Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 7-14-03) 
Sec. 7-1.1. - Same-Definitions. 
    Abandoned motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle which any owner thereof, including any person having a security interest therein, has deserted and left unclaimed on any lot or parcel of ground or upon any right of way within the limits of the city. 
    Accumulation of refuse/trash containers. The storing or permitting the accumulation of refuse, unless such refuse is kept separately in standard refuse/trash containers or dumpsters which are covered by solid, tight fitting lids and which have no uncovered holes, and the storing or permitting the accumulation of refuse and trash for which removal of refuse and trash is not provided, is considered a nuisance. 
    All terrain vehicle. A small, open and motorized buggy or tricycle designed for off-road use. Such vehicles often have over-sized tires to maximize traction in different conditions and may be steered like a bicycle or motorcycle. A standard, non-modified golf cart or lawn mower is not considered an all-terrain vehicle. 
    Approved parking surface. An impervious or somewhat impervious surface that is capable of supporting a vehicle without impacting or disturbing the underlying topsoil. Examples include concrete, asphalt, compacted gravel, inlaid brick or stone or crushed asphalt. 
    Attractive nuisances. The allowing of any physical condition, use or occupancy of any property or premises to be an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, excavations, retaining walls, and unsafe fences is considered a nuisance. 
    Box trailer. An enclosed wheeled vehicle designed for hauling cargo or goods. 
    Compost piles. Any compost pile is considered a nuisance which is of such a nature as to spread or harbor disease, emit unreasonable, unpleasant odors or harmful gas, or attract rodents, vermin or other disease-carrying pests, animals or insects, provided that the presence of earthworms in a compost pile shall not constitute a nuisance. 
    Dangerous trees. The permitting of any tree, shrubbery, hedge or other object adjoining the public rights of way to grow or stand in such a condition that it interferes with the use, construction or maintenance of streets or sidewalks, that could cause injury to streets or sidewalks, or that causes an obstruction to drainage or poses a danger to life, limb or property of persons using the sidewalks or rights of way, is considered a nuisance. 
    Dilapidated structures. All buildings, walls and other structures which have been damaged by fire, decay or otherwise and which are in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay so as not to provide shelter, sufficient sewer, plumbing, electrical or heating facilities or which are unsound or in danger of collapse. 
    Dumpster. The trademarked name of a commercial garbage container made of steel or aluminum, often with a plastic lid and often serviced with a front-end loader or similar truck. Dumpsters are sized or measured by the number of cubic yards of waste that they can contain. 
    Duty of maintenance of private property. No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any property or premises shall maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, nor shall any person keep or maintain such property or premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of the other property in the neighborhood in which such premises property are located. For the purposes of this section, it shall not be essential that the nuisance be created or contributed by the owner, occupant or persons having control or management of the premises, but merely that the nuisance be created or contributed to by licensees, invitees, guests or other persons for whose conduct the owner or operator is responsible, or by persons for whose conduct the owner or operator is not responsible, but by the exercise of reasonable care ought to have become aware. 
    Duty of maintenance of streets, sidewalks, drainage areas and public ways. No person shall place, throw, deposit or allow to accumulate or grow or cause to be erected or placed on any street, alley, sidewalk, gutter, storm sewer, public or private drainage ditch or drainage structure or any other public right of way, easement or public property, any rubbish, garbage, construction or demolition debris, landscaping debris, furniture, signs, large rocks, fences, posts, stakes, weeds, inoperative or unlicensed motor vehicle, junk or scrap metal or other obstruction or encroachment of any nature, except when authorized by the city for a public purpose. Any materials of any kind found on city streets, sidewalks, public ways, public or private drainage areas and other public property may be removed immediately by the city with or without notice to the property owner. 
    Garbage truck. A truck and/or trailer used to collect domestic or commercial refuse, often hauling such waste to a landfill or recycling facility. 
    Graffiti. The illegal or unauthorized defacing of a building, wall, edifice, vehicle, or object by painting or otherwise marking it with words, pictures or symbols. Gang-related markings or symbols are considered graffiti. 
    Hoarding of materials. The accumulation of combustible materials, trash, food, newspapers, magazines, old clothes, metals and other items that create a serious fire and health hazard that can disease, contribute to vermin and/or insect infestations, affect the occupants of buildings, neighbors, public safety personnel and the general public, or violate any other city code, is considered a nuisance. 
    Hoarding of pets. The keeping of more pet animals than can be properly maintained in a healthy condition without presenting a health or safety standard to the owners or others and without constituting a nuisance to the occupants or neighboring properties, characterized by failure to provide proper food, water, shelter, veterinary care and sanitation to the animals resulting in squalid living conditions for the animals and the keeper and by complaints from neighbors including, but not limited to, mistreated or neglected animals, stench from the property and rodent and insect infestations, is considered a nuisance. 
    Junked motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle which constitutes an inoperative motor vehicle as defined under this chapter or which is wrecked, dismantled, discarded or in a state or repair. 
    Motor vehicle. A self-propelled vehicle for use on public roads and highways that require to be registered with the Commonwealth of Kentucky. 
    Motor vehicle or machinery junkyard. Any place where five or more abandoned motor vehicles, inoperative motor vehicles or junked motor vehicles, or automobile and motor vehicle parts, scrap or salvage materials, are deposited, parked or otherwise located. 
    Motor Vehicle Owner. Any individual, firm, corporation or unincorporated association with a claim, either individual or joint, or ownership or any legal or equitable interest in a motor vehicle. 
    Nuisance shall mean a problem structure and any condition or use of public or private property or premises, or of building exteriors which shall substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose, or safety of the public which is detrimental to the property of others, or which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. 
    Utility trailer. A wheeled vehicle which does not have an engine and is designed to haul cargo or goods and can be towed behind another powered vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 14-04, § 2, 10-11-04; Ord. No. 10-07, § 1, 7-9-07; Ord. No. 4-13, § 1, 5-13-13) 
Sec. 7-2. - Same-Right to investigate. 
    Any citation officer or police officer of the city shall the right to investigate any suspected nuisance upon public and private property. Entry into a private building shall require probable cause and follow procedures established by Kentucky statutes. Such citation officer or police officer may also require demonstration 
(Ord. No. 15-97, § 2, 1-12-98) 
Sec. 7-3. - Same-Immediate abatement required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of its owner, agent, or occupant of the lot, building, or place of any kind in the city where any nuisance exists, to abate the same without delay. Where the nuisance cannot be proven to be the responsibility of an occupant of the premises the owner shall be bear the responsibility to abate such nuisance. 
(b)  The city may provide for the restricted entry of dilapidated houses that contain broken windows, doors or other means of ingress by placing barriers over the openings of such structures. Furthermore, city may recoup the costs of remedying the presence of broken windows, doors and other structural or aesthetic deficiencies by placing a material men's lien on the property of the offending party, in accordance with the Kentucky Revised Statutes. 
(c)  If the nuisance is not abated within the time set forth by the code enforcement officer, the city may proceed to abate the nuisance by order of the chairman of the code enforcement board. The code enforcement office shall keep an itemized account of the costs involved in abating the nuisance. Such costs may be placed as a lien on the property on which the nuisance occurred, or on the city tax bill of the property on which the nuisance occurred. The city may seek remedies in graves district or circuit court. Appeals of the amounts listed by the code enforcement office may be appealed within seven days of receipt by the owner or tenant to the code enforcement board. A standard materialman's lien of $125.00/hour shall apply to all abatements in which city employees or its agents participate in the abatement process. All costs, including recording fees, will be added on in addition to the standard materialman's lien. 
(Ord. No. 15-97, § 2, 1-12-98; Ord. No. 15-03, § 2, 7-14-03; Ord. No. 10-07, § 3, 7-9-07; Ord. No. 6-09, § 1, 6-8-09) 
Sec. 7-4. - Same-Notice and time to abate. 
    Whenever, the administrator or administrator's designee shall learn of the existence within the city of an article of condition so kept or maintained as to be a nuisance under the terms of this article, or which is a nuisance under the common law or statutes of this state, he shall notify in writing the owner or occupant of the premises upon which the nuisance is situated to abate the same within three days, except in circumstances where the administrator or administrator's designee deems that it is necessary to allow a longer period of time to comply. In such circumstances the direction may allow up to a maximum of 30 days for compliance. If the owner or occupant cannot be located or refuses to accept written notice tendered to such person, notice to such owner or occupant shall be given by affixing a copy thereof to the offending object and in a conspicuous place at the entrance of any residence or place of business on the premises on which the offending object or condition is situated. 
(Ord. No. 15-97, § 2, 1-12-98) 
Sec. 7-5. - Failure to abate. 
    In the event that the owner or occupant of such premises fails to abate the nuisance after notice, the administrator or administrator's designee, shall cause the object creating the nuisance to be removed or the condition creating the nuisance to be remedied. The ownership of offending objects removed by the city hereunder shall be vested in the city. The costs of removal of an offending object (after deduction of any salvage value thereof) and costs of remedying of an offending condition, may be collected from the owner or occupant of the premises on which the offending object or condition was situated, and if said incurred costs are not immediately paid, said costs may be added to the tax bill of the owner or occupant of the premises and same shall be a lien with the same lien rights upon all the property of the owner or occupant as provided in the Kentucky Revised Statutes. 
    Property subject to a lien for unpaid nuisance abatement charges may be sold for nonpayment and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the nuisance abatement charges and attorneys' fees after deducting other city incurred expenses. Such foreclosure shall be brought in the name of the city by the city attorney. The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings, in the name of the city, in any court having jurisdiction over the matter, against any property for which the bill has remained unpaid 60 days after it has been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 15-97, § 2, 1-12-98; Ord. No. 4-13, § 2, 5-13-13) 
Sec. 7-6. - Noises-Prohibition; enumeration. 
    The creation of certain unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises within the city is hereby declared to be a nuisance and prohibited. The following are declared to be such loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises within the meaning of this section: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control; or if in motion, at any time, the sounding of any horn or signal device except wherever necessary as a warning of the approach of such vehicle to pedestrians or other vehicles; the creation by means of any such signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. 
(2)  Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any hospital, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any person in the vicinity. 
(3)  The keeping of any dog or other animal which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person in the vicinity. 
(4)  The use of any automobile, motorcycle, street car or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(5)  To discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorcycle, motor vehicle or motor boat engine except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noise therefrom. 
(6)  The use of any drum, loud speaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale or display of merchandise, or the use of mechanical loud speakers, amplifiers, bands, orchestras of musical instruments on trucks or other moving or standing vehicles for commercial advertising; provided, however, the use of such loud speakers, musical instruments or other devices enumerated herein shall not be unlawful if there has been issued to the person using the same a permit signed by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 8-25-69, § 1) 
State Law reference- Authority to develop comprehensive noise regulations, KRS 224.30-175. 
Sec. 7-7. - Same-Tests and standards. 
(a)  Factors to consider: The standards which shall be considered in determining whether a violation of section 7-4 exists shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The volume of the noise. 
(2)  The intensity of the noise. 
(3)  Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual. 
(4)  Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural. 
(5)  The volume and intensity of the background noise, if any. 
(6)  The proximity of the noise to residential sleeping facilities. 
(7)  The nature and zoning of the area within which the noise emanates. 
(8)  The density of inhabitation of the area within which the noise emanates. 
(9)  The time of the day or night the noise occurs. 
(10)  The duration of the noise. 
(11)  Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent or constant. 
(12)  Whether the noise is produced by a commercial or noncommercial activity. 
(b)  Tables.

Sec. 7-8. - Same-Exemption for public vehicles. 
    None of the terms or prohibitions in section 7-4 shall apply to or be enforced against any vehicle of the city while engaged upon necessary public business. 
(Ord. of 8-25-69, § 2) 
Sec. 7-8.5. - Prohibited noise offenses. 
(a)  General prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any loud or unreasonable noise as defined in this article. Unreasonable noise disturbs, injures or endangers the peace or health of another or the health, safety, or welfare of the community. Such noise constitutes the disturbance of the peace and a public nuisance. Loud and unreasonable noise, for the purpose of this article, is defined as noise that is plainly audible to a reasonable person of normal sensitivities using his or her unaided hearing faculties as such times and distances proscribed below. To be plainly audible does not require the listener to be able to determine specific characteristics of the noise, e.g., the words of a song being played, but only that the listener hears the noise, e.g., the boom of the song's bass. 
(b)  Express prohibitions. The following acts are noise disturbances: 
(1)  Radios, television sets, musical instruments, phonographs, and similar devices, including motor vehicle sound equipment. The operation or permitting the use or operation of any musical instrument, radio, television, phonograph, or other device for the production or reproduction of sound in such a manner as to be plainly audible: 
a.  From the source of the noise through the walls separating any occupied unit within the same building; 
b.  From the source of the noise to within a occupied building located on another property than that from which the noise emanates; or 
c.  From the source of the noise within the right-of-way to within an occupied building; or 
d.  From the source of the noise a distance of 50 feet or greater. 
(2)  Parties and other social events. In the event the source of the proscribed noise is a private party or social event, the responsible person for the offense shall be any or all of the following: 
a.  The owner of the premises; 
b.  The occupant of the premises; or 
c.  The person authorized to make use of the premises for such event. 
(3)  Machinery and construction noise. Machinery and construction noise that is plainly audible at any distance, but reasonable to the nature of the work performed is not prohibited under this article from the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Such noise that is plainly audible from the source of the noise a distance of 50 feet is prohibited between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Excepted from this prohibition is works necessitated by an emergency. The determination of whether or not an emergency exists for the purpose of this article shall be made by the mayor, chief of police or ranking police officer on duty at the time of the emergency. 
(4)  Loudspeakers utilized for commercial purposes. Noise from loudspeakers used for commercial purposes and used in the ordinary course of business, i.e., ice cream truck or auction that is plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet is not prohibited under this article from the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(5)  Noise not otherwise prohibited (in specific provisions above). Noise from any other source, including, but not limited to, barking dogs, car engines, human voices and fire works, which are plainly audible: 
a.  From the source of the noise through the walls separating any occupied unit within the same building; 
b.  From the source of the noise to within a occupied building located on another property than that from which the noise emanates; or 
c.  From the source of the noise within the right-of-way to within an occupied building; or 
d.  From the source of the noise a distance of 50 feet or greater. 
(c)  Exemptions. Noise from the following sources is exempt from the prohibition specified above: 
(1)  Governmental activities. Governmental vehicles and equipment while in use for municipal purposes, including, but not limited to, safety signals, warning devices, snow removal, public events, law enforcement, emergency construction or repair work. Events conducted by or permitted by the city must comply with all conditions of such permits with respect to noise control issues; 
(2)  Special events. Special events permitted by the appropriate agency, e.g., Graves County Fair; and 
(3)  Essential activities. Activities for which an exemption has been obtained from the office of the mayor, which exemptions shall be issued only for those activities for which there is a substantial need and the effectiveness of which would be significantly reduced or eliminated by the enforcement of this prohibition. Exemptions under this section shall issue for only that period during which the need for the activity can be demonstrated. 
(d)  Enforcement of article. 
(1)  Authority to enforce this article is given to the police department and the code enforcement officers. 
(2)  The penalty for violation of this article is as follows: 
a.  First offense. For the first offense a fine of $100.00; 
b.  Second offense. For the second offense within 12 months, a fine of $200.00; 
c.  Third and subsequent offenses. For the third and subsequent offenses within 12 months, a fine of $500.00. 
(3)  Payment of fines; penalty for nonpayment: Within seven days from the date of the issuance of the citation, any person cited pursuant to this article shall: 
a.  Pay to the city the civil penalty prescribed; or 
b.  Request a hearing regarding such citation and/or penalty before the code enforcement board. 
c.  Failure to pay the citation or request a hearing within the required seven days shall result in the code enforcement board's entry of a final order determining: 
1.  The person cited to have waived his or her right to a hearing; 
2.  The citation and fine to be proper under this article; and 
3.  The assessment of an administrative fee in an amount equal to the original citation fine. 
(4)  All fines shall be payable at the office of the city clerk at 211 East Broadway, Mayfield, Kentucky. 
(e)  Section established as law. It is hereby ordained by the City Council of the City of Mayfield, Kentucky, that the restrictions, requirements and definitions herein contained shall be established as law. 
(Ord. No. 3-06, §§ I-IV, 2-13-06) 
Sec. 7-9. - Fluoridation of water. 
    There shall be installed and maintained the required, approved equipment for the distribution of fluoride in the city's public water supply, and fluoride shall be distributed in the public water supply through the municipal water works system in quantities recommended and approved by the appropriate authority. The cost of the chemical fluoride, the expense of installation of any necessary machinery for the proper distribution of said chemical in the public water system, and the maintenance of this equipment and machinery, and all other expenses pertaining to the use of fluoride in the public water system shall be borne by the city water system. 
(Ord. of 1-14-52, §§ 2, 3) 
Sec. 7-10. - Use of public sewer. 
    The owners or persons in control of improved real estate in the city are prohibited from the use of outdoor toilets or open pit privies in disposing of human waste in connection with the use of said property, and all of said outdoor toilets and open pit privies are hereby condemned, and all owners or persons in control of improved real estate in the city where human inhabitants live shall henceforth be required to install running water and indoor toilets to dispose of human waste and in addition sinks shall be required in all kitchen units. All human waste shall be disposed of in the public sewer system. 
(Ord. of 7-11-60, § 2) 
Cross reference- Required connection, § 8-2. 
Sec. 7-11. - Smoke. 
    The emission or escape of soot, dense smoke or cinders from any smokestack, chimney or other part of any locomotive, stationary engine, steam roller, steam derrick, steam pile-driver, steam shovel, tar kettle or any other similar machine or contrivance or of any building or premises, used or employed in the city; shall be deemed and is hereby declared a public nuisance and is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 7-20-31, § 1) 
Secs. 7-12-7-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTER; UNLAWFUL ACCUMULATIONS; WEEDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisance, § 7-1(2)-(6), (9), (12), (19); maintenance and cleanliness of sidewalks, § 14-1. 

Sec. 7-20. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the following terms have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Dumpout: Any material emptied from a vehicle or building upon streets, roadsides, or public places other than that emptied in appropriate litter receptacles. 
    Handbill: Any printed or written material excluding newspapers, which advertises for sale any commodity, or thing, or which directs attention to any business or other activity, or event of any kind. 
    Litter: Any solid waste, including but not limited to, containers, packages, wrappings, printed matter or other material thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, but not including the wastes of the primary processes of mining, logging, sawmilling, farming or manufacturing. 
    Litter bag: A bag, sack, or other container made of any material which is large enough to serve as a receptacle for litter inside the vehicle or watercraft of any person. 
    Litter receptacle: A container meeting the requirements of the department for natural resources and environmental protection. 
    Newspaper: Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law. 
    Park: A reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other areas in the city devoted to active or passive outdoor recreation. 
    Private property: Any property not publicly owned or held for use by the public. 
    Public place: Any area that is used or held for use by the public, whether owned or operated by the public or private interests. 
    Solid waste: Any putrescible and nonputrescible solid and semi-solid waste, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, industrial wastes, swill, demolition and construction wastes, abandoned vehicles or parts thereof, and discarded commodities. 
    Street: Synonymous with and includes any highway, road, alley, collector, local, arterial or freeway within the political subdivision. 
    Sweepouts: Any collection of debris, resulting from clean-up operations, that is deposited in or around a public place. 
    Vehicle: Includes every device capable of being moved upon a public street and in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public street. 
(Ord. of 4-14-80, § 3) 
Sec. 7-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to accomplish litter control in the city. This article is intended to place upon all persons within the city the duty of contributing to the public cleanliness and appearance in the city in order to promote the public health, safety and welfare and to protect the economic interests of the people of the city against unsanitary and unsightly conditions. It is further the intent of this article to protect the people against the health and safety menace and the expense incident to littering. 
(Ord. of 4-14-80, § 2) 
Sec. 7-22. - Enforcement officers and procedures. 
    Enforcement of this article may be by any police officer. All such enforcement officers are empowered to issue citations to and/or arrest without warrant, persons violating the provision of this article. Said enforcement officers may serve and execute all warrants, citations, and other processes issued by the courts. In addition, mailing by registered or certified mail of such warrant, citation, or other process to the last known place of residence of the offender shall be deemed personal service upon the person charged. 
(Ord. of 4-14-80, § 14) 
Sec. 7-23. - Penalties. 
(a)  In arriving at realistic penalties for violations of provisions contained in this article, the primary objective has been to establish them as part of the simplest possible enforcement system. The system has these features: 
(1)  A mail-in ticket which: 
(a)  Identifies the violator. 
(b)  Lists and identifies violations of the provisions by section numbers. 
(c)  States the prescribed fine beside each violation listed. 
(d)  Provides simple instructions on where the ticket is to be mailed with a check or money order in the amount of the stipulated fine. 
(e)  States a simple procedure to follow if the violator elects to appear in court to plead the case rather than mail in the fine. 
(2)  Use of the above ticket by all department and agency personnel authorized to enforce sections of this article. 
(3)  Use for particularly flagrant violations (dumpouts, garbage spreading from badly-overloaded solid waste containers, debris-strewn property, etc.). This would be in the form of a direct summons to court, with penalty range substantially above those on the mail-in ticket. 
(b)  The schedule of penalties for violations of this article is as follows: 
    VIOLATION       AMOUNT

(Ord. of 4-14-80, § 17; Ord. No. 9-94, § 1, 8-8-94) 
Sec. 7-24. - Littering-Generally. 
(a)  No person shall throw, drop, deposit, discard or otherwise dispose of litter upon any public place, or upon any private property not owned by such person or in any waters within the jurisdiction of the city, whether from a vehicle or otherwise, except: 
(1)  When such property is designated by the state or by any of its agencies or the city for disposal of garbage and refuse, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to so use such property; or 
(2)  Into a litter receptacle or other container, for a temporary period of less than 14 days, in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried away or deposited by the elements upon any part of said public places or any private property and provided that such litter receptacle or other container is placed out for pick-up along the street no sooner than 24 hours prior to and removed no later than 24 hours after the scheduled pick-up time. 
    In addition, such litter receptacle or container shall otherwise be stored beyond the front building line of the house or 25 feet from the back of curb or edge of pavement, whichever is greater, at all times, excluding the times specified above. Those individuals, entities, etc., not having scheduled pick-up times from a private waste hauler shall maintain litter receptacles or containers facilities beyond the front building line of the house or 25 feet from the back of curb or edge of pavement, whichever is greater, at all times. Litter receptacles or containers provided by the City of Mayfield or Graves County for the public and dumpsters shall be excluded. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and in addition to or in lieu of any other penalty, such person may, in the sound discretion of the court, be directed by the court to pick up and remove from any public place or any private property, with permission of the owner, or the person in possession, of the property, upon which it is established that such person has deposited litter, all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of the execution of sentence. 
(Ord. of 4-14-80, § 4; Ord. No. 9-94, § 2, 8-8-94) 
Cross reference- Placing refuse in manhole, § 8-5. 
State Law reference- Criminal littering, KRS 512.070. 
Sec. 7-25. - Same-From vehicle. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any public street unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from dropping, shifting, leaking or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand or gravel may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other substance may be sprinkled on a roadway surface in the cleaning or maintaining of such roadway by public authority having jurisdiction for the same or by persons under contract or other authorization by such public authority. 
(b)  Any person owning or operating a vehicle from which any glass or other objects of its load have fallen or escaped, which would constitute an obstruction or damage a vehicle or otherwise endanger travel upon such public street shall immediately cause such public street to be cleaned of all such glass or other objects and shall pay any cost therefor. 
(c)  When any garbage, rubbish or other materials are removed from private property, the person so removing same shall not leave any of said garbage, rubbish or other materials at or near the cans where said garbage or rubbish has been deposited or any other place on private property. 
(Ord. of 12-11-72, § 2; Ord. of 4-14-80, § 13) 
Sec. 7-26. - Hours of transportation of garbage and rubbish. 
    All garbage and rubbish, including limbs, leaves, paper cartons, bricks and other trash by vehicles in the city shall be limited to the hours of 6:00 a.m. through 8:00 p.m. of each day with the following exceptions: Solid waste (trash) pick-up shall be permitted at any time in the areas outlined on a detailed map, copies of which are on file in the offices of the city clerk, the city building official and the city planner and herein referred to as the "City's Solid Waste Map". 
(Ord. of 12-11-72, § 2; Ord. No. 10-98, § I, 7-13-98) 
Sec. 7-27. - Unlawful accumulations and growths. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant, or any agent, servant, representative or employee of any such owner, lessee, or occupant having control of any lot or land or any part thereof in the city to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, or on or along the sidewalk, street or alley adjacent to the same between the property line and the curb or middle of the alley or for ten feet outside the property line if there by no curb, the collection of rubbish, trash, stagnate water, or any growth of weeds, grass or other rank vegetation to a greater height than ten inches, or any accumulation of dead weeds, grass or brush. It shall also be unlawful for any such person to cause, suffer or allow poison ivy, rag weed or other poisonous plants, or plants detrimental to health to grow on any such lot or land in such manner that any part of such ivy, rag weed, or other poisonous or harmful weed shall extend upon, overhang or border any public place, or allow seed, pollen or other poisonous particles or emanations therefrom to be carried through the air into or onto any public place. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owner, lessee or occupant of any lot or land in the city to remove rubbish, trash, and stagnate water, and to cut and remove or cause to be cut and removed all such weeds, grass or other rank, poisonous or harmful vegetation as often as be necessary to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. of 6-29-65, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 4-11, § 1, 5-9-2011) 
Sec. 7-28. - Issues that constitute an endangerment to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(a)  Parking restrictions in residential districts or those structures used for residential purposes. 
(1)  a.  No semi-tractor trailer, no dump truck, no garbage truck, no pump out truck, no chemical truck, no gasoline truck or no similar vehicle, or any vehicle or trailer designed to transport waste or hazardous or noxious materials, shall be parked or stored in any residentially zoned district, or those structures used for residential purposes, or stored in the street right-of-way. 
b.  Exceptions are commercial vehicles during the actual performance of a temporary service on the property where it is parked, a vehicle making a bona fide pickup or delivery of property or merchandise and emergency vehicles. 
c.  Semi tractors are allowed if they are parked out of the right-of-way and on an approved parking surface. 
d.  Construction equipment that does not pose a nuisance to the public by emitting foul odors or loud noise is allowed on a temporary or occasional basis if they are parked on an approved surface and out of the right-of-way. 
e.  Utility trailers, box trailers or similar vehicles are not allowed to be parked in the right-of-way, except during times in which they are being used for the actual performance of a temporary service or are being used to load or unload cargo or goods. 
(2)  Parking any motor vehicle on unpaved or otherwise pervious area is prohibited. The parking, displaying or storing of any motor vehicle on any grass surface in any residential zone or those structures used for residential purposes is prohibited, except that one designated parking space may be located on the grass in a required front set back adjacent to and parallel to the driveway located on the property. The size of such designated parking space shall not exceed 9 feet × 19 feet. Access to such designated parking space shall be by way of the property's driveway. If the designated parking space is not maintained with adequate grasses or other plants and/or landscaping materials to keep the area from becoming rutted, muddy and/or soil from being blown or washed away and is identified as a violation of this provision, such designated parking area shall be paved or graveled within 30 days of a written notice from the office of code enforcement. Exceptions may be made for parking on a pervious area on a temporary basis, such as for holiday guest parking, unloading a vehicle, washing a vehicle or for other justifiable reasons. 
(3)  Variances. In instances where strict enforcement of the requirements of subsection (2) would cause undue hardship due to circumstances unique to the individual property under consideration, and the spirit and intent of the ordinance is not entirely compromised, the board of zoning adjustments may grant dimensional variances from the strict terms of said ordinance. The applicant must show in good faith that due to the exceptional narrowness, shallowness, size or shape of a specific piece of property, or where by reason of exceptional topographic conditions or an extraordinary circumstance that a hardship is present. 
(4)  Not more than four unsheltered vehicles shall remain at any residence for a period longer than 72 hours. Houses that do not have a garage or carport may apply for a variance from this requirement. Residents who do have a garage or carport are to use that space for the storage of vehicles, if more than four vehicles are present at the residence for periods exceeding 72 hours. Residents with exceptional circumstances may apply for a variance. 
(b)  Public burning. The intentional outdoor burning of any material, structure, matter or thing unless specifically authorized by the fire chief is a nuisance. 
(c)  Storage of garbage cans, dumpsters or refuse receptacles. Garbage cans, dumpsters or refuse receptacles must be stored behind the front building line of a structure, excluding porches, and must be stored in a side or rear yard. Trash receptacles cannot be stored in a side yard of a corner lot adjacent to the right-of-way. 
(d)  Clotheslines. Clotheslines in any front or side yard area or on any porch are a nuisance. Railings cannot be used as a clothesline. Laundry cannot be displayed on the front porch. Clotheslines may not be located in a side yard of a corner lot adjacent to the right-of-way. 
(e)  Graffiti. Permitting or allowing any graffiti to remain on any building, wall, fence, vehicle or structure for a period in excess of five days is a nuisance. 
(f)  Use of property for living, sleeping or cooking purposes. The use of property or buildings or portions thereof for living, sleeping or cooking purposes which were not designed or intended to be used for such occupancies is a nuisance. 
(g)  Sweeping or blowing yard waste into street. Sweeping, blowing or otherwise conducting grass clippings, leaves or any type of yard waste into any street in the city is a nuisance. 
(h)  Use of private property under 17 acres for all recreational driving of terrain vehicles, etc. The use of private property less than 17 acres, for the recreational driving of all terrain vehicles, motorcycles, mini-bikes, motorized scooters, dune buggies, or similar vehicles that may cause loud or obnoxious noises or may substantially disturb the topsoil is a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 10-07, § 2, 7-9-07) 
Sec. 7-29. - Storage of abandoned vehicles, inoperative motor vehicles, junked motor vehicles or scrap metal. 
    No person or commercial business shall keep, store, place or allow to remain in open view, any abandoned motor vehicle, inoperative motor vehicle, junked motor vehicle, scrap metal, automobile and motor vehicle parts, or related refuse or rubbish from any such vehicle or parts, upon any lot or parcel of ground or right of way within the city limits, except upon premises authorized by the city for such purposes. 
    This prohibition upon keeping, storing, placing or allowing to remain in open view, any abandoned motor vehicle, inoperative motor vehicle, junked motor vehicle or related refuse or rubbish from any such vehicle or parts, upon any lot or parcel of ground or right of way within the city limits applies jointly and severally to the owner(s) of the subject motor vehicle or item and the owner(s) of the real property upon which such motor vehicle or item is located. 
    The chief of police, code enforcement officer and/or their designees are hereby granted the authority to city any person in violation of this chapter. Any person cited for a violation of this section shall have ten days from the date of citation in which to cure such violation or make arrangements with the chief of police or code enforcement officer for the cure of such violation. If the violation is not cured within ten days the chief of police, code enforcement officer and/or their designees are hereby authorized to enter upon the property where the violation exists and to remove, transport and store the motor vehicle(s) or item which constitutes the violation. 
    The city shall not be responsible for any damage to any abandoned motor vehicle, junked motor vehicle, automobile and motor vehicle parts, related refuse or rubbish from such vehicles or parts, or the real property upon which such motor vehicle or item is located, which results from the removal, transportation or storage of such motor vehicle or item. After the offending motor vehicle or item has been removed to a storage facility, the city and any private person or entity who has taken possession of the motor vehicle or item for storage shall have a lien on the motor vehicle or item, which may be enforced pursuant to KRS 376.275. The owner of the motor vehicle or item may redeem such motor vehicle or item within 20 days after its removal, said redemption shall be at the sole expense of the owner of said motor vehicle or item. At the expiration of the 20-day period, the storage lot owner or the city shall dispose of the motor vehicle or item in any matter deemed appropriate by that person or entity. 
    Any person designated by the chief of police, or his or her subordinates within the city police department to remove, transport or store any motor vehicle or item pursuant to this chapter shall have a superior lien on the motor vehicle or item for the reasonable charges of the removal, transportation or storage of the motor vehicle or item, and such person may sell such motor vehicle or item for the payment of said charges upon compliance with the provisions of KRS 376.275 and KRS 376.280 related to notice and sale of motor vehicles for such charges. 
(Ord. No. 4-13, § 3, 5-13-13) 
Sec. 7-30. - Unlawful removal of code enforcement signs. 
    Any person unlawfully removing a code enforcement sign from any property on which it is placed by a code enforcement officer, police officer, or other designated employee, shall be subject to a criminal citation that will result in a criminal fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $100.00. Subsequent violations by the same person will result in the person being subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 2-14, § 1, 2-10-14) 
Secs. 7-31-7-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - USE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS IN BUILDINGS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC PROHIBITED 

Sec. 7-41. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Building means any structure open to the public that is enclosed from the weather, whether or not the windows or doors are actually left open. If a person owns, leases, or possesses only a portion of a building, the term building applies to the ownership, leasehold, or possessory interest as well. 
    Common Area means any area where individuals may congregate such as hallways, lobbies, restrooms, and elevators. 
    Dwelling means any place used primarily for sleeping overnight and conducting activities of daily living, including, without limitation, a hotel or motel room or suite, or a hospital, hospice, or nursing home room. 
    Enclosed area means any place that: 
(1)  Is closed overhead by a roof or other covering of any material, whether permanent or temporary; and 
(2)  Has 40 percent or more of its perimeter closed in by walls or other coverings of any material, whether permanent or temporary. 
    Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profit, and a person who volunteers his or her services for a non-profit entity. 
    Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, unincorporated association, limited liability company, corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or non-profit entity that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
    Person shall include the owner, lessee, principal manager, or any individual or corporation, limited liability company, business, partnership, association, unincorporated association, municipal corporation, trust, or any non-profit entity having control of a building, as the term building is defined herein, or the agent or employee of any such owner, lessee, principal manager, individual or corporation. 
    Private organization means an establishment which maintains selective members, is operated by the membership, does not provide food, drink, entertainment, or lodging for pay to anyone who is not a member or accompanied by a member and is not profit oriented. 
    Retail tobacco store means a retail store devoted primarily to the sale of any tobacco product, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco and chewing tobacco, and accessories in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. The sale of such other products shall be considered incidental if such sales generate less than one-third of the total annual gross sales. 
    Smoke or smoking shall mean the act of possessing, carrying, burning, inhaling or exhaling the smoke of any lighted cigarette, cigar, or pipe, or other combustible tobacco product. 
    Tobacco warehouse means any warehouse building offering tobacco for purchase at auction and meeting the definition established in KRS 248.010(4). 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 2, 7-8-13) 
Sec. 7-42. - Prohibition. 
(a)  No person shall smoke within any building or enclosed area except in one of the following locations: 
(1)  In any dwelling, unless the dwelling is also used as a childcare facility, adult day care center, or meets the definition of a common area as defined herein. 
(2)  In a building, room, or hall being used by a person or group for a purely private social function that is not open to the public nor is admittance obtained by purchase of a ticket or the making of a donation; in any room used for psychological treatment of nicotine addiction by a licensed healthcare professional or in a physically separate and independently ventilated room in a hospital, hospice facility, or nursing home open to all residents as a smoking room and for no other purpose. 
(3)  In a retail tobacco store. 
(4)  Indoor smoking areas provided in state or federal governmental office buildings or workplaces pursuant to KRS 61.165. 
(5)  Facilities not open to the public operated by private organizations. 
(6)  In a tobacco warehouse. 
(7)  In a completely confined area that meets the requirements of an UL listed assembly of a smoke proof enclosure; that contains a HVAC system designed in accordance with the current edition of state adopted International Mechanical Code, and that meets any additional requirements of the city building code advisory committee and building codes department. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall prevent a person in control of any place whatsoever from prohibiting smoking completely in such place, and no person shall fail to abide by such a private prohibition. 
(c)  Nothing in this chapter shall authorize smoking in any place where it is otherwise prohibited by statute, ordinance, regulation, or by order of the fire marshall. 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 3, 7-8-13) 
Sec. 7-43. - Posting signs. 
(a)  Not less than two no smoking signs or the international no smoking symbol consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in every building and enclosed area. The party responsible for the placement of the signage is the owner, employer, operator, lessee, manager, or other person in control of the building or enclosed area. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall authorize the removal of no-smoking signs required by other statute, regulation, or ordinance. 
(c)  All ashtrays or ash containers shall be removed from buildings and enclosed areas, except for ashtrays for sale and not for use on the premises. Any permanent structure that previously functioned or was used as an ashtray shall be disabled or altered to prevent its use as an ashtray. 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 4, 7-8-13) 
Sec. 7-44. - Reasonable distance. 
    Smoking is prohibited within a reasonable distance from the outside entrance to any building or enclosed area so as to ensure that tobacco smoke does not enter the building or enclosed area through entrances, windows, ventilation systems, or other means. Unless directed otherwise by the mayor, the distance of 15 feet shall be deemed reasonable. 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 5, 7-8-13) 
Sec. 7-45. - Non-retaliation and non-waiver of rights. 
    No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment or customer because that employee, applicant for emoployment or customer exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 6, 7-8-13) 
Sec. 7-46. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The mayor's office shall designate the city departments responsible for enforcing this article. 
(b)  Written notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to all applicants for a business license within the city. 
(c)  Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with a written complaint to the mayor. 
(d)  The following departments, or their designees, shall, while performing otherwise legal inspections inspect for compliance with this article: Fire department, building inspections, public works department, and city clerk's office. 
(e)  A person in control of a building or enclosed area shall inform persons violating this article of the applicable provisions thereof and report non-compliance to the mayor. 
(f)  No person having control of a building or enclosed area shall fail to: 
(1)  Immediately ask smokers to refrain from smoking in any no smoking area; 
(2)  Use any other legal means which may be appropriate to further the intent of this chapter, including the action required by subsection (e). 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the city, or any person aggrieved by a failure to comply with this article, whether by commission or omission, including violations on the part of a person in control of a building or enclosed area covered by this article may bring legal action to enforce this article, either by civil action seeking injunctive relief or by criminal complaint in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 7, 7-8-13) 
Sec. 7-47. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a violation of the same, which violation shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding $50.00. 
(b)  A person in control of a building or enclosed area who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a violation punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding $50.00 for a first violation within a 12-month period. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding $100.00 for a second violation within a 12-month period. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding $250.00 for each additional violation within a 12-month period. 
(c)  Persons who smoke in an area where smoking is prohibited by this article and who refuse to extinguish their smoking material when asked, may be required to leave the premises, and shall be subject to prosecution for trespass if they do not leave when asked. 
(d)  In addition to the fines established by this section, violation of this article by a person who controls a building or enclosed area more than three times in any 12-month period may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or business license issued by the city to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(e)  Violation of this article is declared to be a public nuisance which may be abated by the city or its designated agents by restraining order, preliminary or permanent injunction or other means provided for by law. The city may recover the reasonable costs of any court enforcement action seeking abatement of this nuisance. 
(f)  Each calendar day on which a violation of this article occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 6-13, § 8, 7-8-13) 
Chapter 8 - MUNICIPAL UTILITIES AND SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ambulance service, § 6-2 et seq.; water and sewer employee pension, § 12-13. 
State Law reference- Utilities in cities, KRS ch. 96. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    City sanitary sewer mains, city sewer mains or sewer mains: City sanitary sewers for the collection of house and business drainage that lie in the middle of the street or run parallel with the street. 
    House and business drainage: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a house or business drainage system which receives the discharge from within the walls of a house, except basement drains used to eliminate water which has seeped through the concrete walls of said basement and drains used to funnel water in connection with washing automobiles, trucks, etc. 
    Real estate with improvements thereon or improved real estate: Any house, dwelling, business house, or building located on real estate in this city that contains facilities for house or business drainage. 
    Sewer laterals or laterals: The piping that runs from the city sewer mains at a right angle to the edge of the pavement, or street curb, or the edge of the gravel portion of a gravel street. 
(Ord. of 12-13-54, § 1) 
Sec. 8-2. - Sewer connection-Required before occupancy. 
    The owners or persons in control of all real estate located in the city shall connect same with city sewer mains or laterals by running and laying at their own expense the necessary pipes to connect their house and business drainage to the city sewer mains or laterals and each improvement upon real estate, before same is occupied, shall be connected with the city sanitary sewer mains or laterals. 
(Ord. of 12-13-54, § 3) 
Cross reference- Use of public sewer, § 7-8. 
Sec. 8-3. - Same-Permit; performance. 
    The owners or persons in control of all improved real estate, contractors and all other individuals shall under no circumstances make a connection with a city sanitary sewer main or lateral without first applying for and receiving a written permit to make such connection from the superintendent of the water and sewer board; and contractors, owners and other persons in control of all improved real estate shall further make such connection to the city sanitary sewer mains or laterals according to directions and under the supervision of the proper officials. The city or its agent shall be permitted to inspect any connection made to the city sewer mains or laterals after said connection is completed and before said connection is covered with soil. 
(Ord. of 12-13-54, § 5; Ord. of 11-25-57, § 2A) 
Sec. 8-4. - Tampering with meters. 
    Any person who tampers with electric meters or water meters by breaking the seal thereon, or attaching wire, pipe, or other device which would permit the flow of unmetered or unauthorized electricity or water to the benefit of the premises where said meters are located, or to any person, is in violation of Kentucky Revised Statute, section 514.060, and persons adjudged guilty thereof shall be fined in the district court in accordance with the penalties set out in the Kentucky Revised Statutes for those adjudged guilty thereof. 
(Ord. of 1-9-78, § 11) 
Sec. 8-5. - Removal of man-hole covers; placing refuse therein. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any sewer manhole cover in the city, or to deposit any trash, refuse or other substance in same. 
(Ord. of 10-1-28, § 1) 
Cross reference- Littering, § 7-24. 
Sec. 8-6. - Illegal use of water; wasting water. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person having a license or permit from, or an agreement with, the city or its agent for the use of water from the water works, to use, or allow to be used, for other purposes than those specified in the license or permit, or knowingly to permit any person not authorized to take or use water from any hydrant or connection on the premises or under the control of such person, or to permit the water to run therefrom without being used. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, personally or by any person acting under such person's authority, to use or take water from any part of the water works without a license or permit, or without authority, to open, connect to, dig out, cover over, deface, destroy, remove or obstruct any fire plug, hydrant, cock valve, valve box, fountain or other fixture or connection of the water works, or to turn on or shut off water into or from any pipes wherever situated, or make any alteration or extension of, or in any street service or house pipe or street main. 
(Ord. of 6-23-19, § 2) 
Sec. 8-7. - Climbing standpipe, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to climb upon the standpipe of the water system except employees thereof. 
(Ord. of 6-23-19, § 3) 
Sec. 8-8. - Trimming of trees. 
    For the purpose of protecting and preserving the electric lines of the city, the city or its agent shall have the power to trim or cut limbs of trees, belonging to abutting property owners, which in any matter hinder, touch or obstruct the above mentioned lines. 
(Ord. of 5-27-18, § 1)

(Ord. No. 4-99, § I, 4-12-99; Ord. No. 16-06, § 1, 10-9-06) 
Sec. 8-10. - Charges for users of wastewater system. 
(a)  It is determined and declared to be necessary and conducive to the protection of the public health, safety, welfare and convenience of the City of Mayfield and its Mayfield Electric and Water Systems to collect charges from all users who contribute wastewater to the Mayfield treatment works or otherwise are served by the Mayfield treatment works. The proceeds of such charges so derived will be used for the purpose of operating and maintaining the public wastewater treatment works. 
(b)  Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this section shall be as follows: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation or organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees C, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    Commercial user shall mean all retail stores, restaurants, office buildings, laundries, and other private business and service establishments. 
    Debt service shall mean charges levied on users of the wastewater treatment works to support the annual debt service obligations of the system. 
    Governmental user shall include legislative, judicial, administrative and regulatory activities of federal, state and local governments. 
    Industrial user (IU) shall mean a source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a discharge of pollutants under regulations issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Clean Water Act. 
    Institutional user shall include social, charitable, religious, and educational activities such as schools, churches, hospitals, nursing homes, penal institutions and similar institutional users. 
    Normal domestic wastewater shall mean wastewater that has a BOD concentration of not more than 200 mg/l and a suspended solids concentration of not more than 250 mg/l and any other pollutant. 
    Operation and maintenance shall mean those functions that result in expenditures during the useful life of the sewerage system for materials, labor, utilities and other items which are necessary for managing and for which such works were designed and constructed. The term, operation and maintenance includes replacement as defined in subsection (d). 
    Replacement shall mean expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the sewerage system to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
    Residential user shall mean any contributor to the Mayfield Treatment Works whose lot, parcel, or real estate, or building is used for domestic dwelling purposes only. 
    Shall is mandatory; may is permissive. 
    SS (denoting suspended solids) shall mean solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Treatment works shall mean any devices and systems for the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal wastewater, domestic wastewater or liquid industrial wastes. These include intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, wastewater collection systems, pumping, power, and other equipment and their appurtenances; extensions, improvements, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof, elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply such as standby treatment units and clear well facilities; and any works, including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such treatment (including land for composting sludge, temporary storage of such compost and land used for the storage of treated wastewater in land treatment systems before land application); or any other method or system for preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal waste or industrial waste, including waste in combined storm water and sanitary sewer systems. 
    Useful life shall mean the estimated period during which a treatment works will be operated. 
    User charge shall mean the total wastewater service charge which is levied in a proportional and adequate manner for the cost of operation, maintenance, replacement and debt service expenses of the wastewater treatment works. 
    Water meter shall mean a water volume measuring and recording device, furnished and/or installed by a user and approved by the Mayfield Electric and Water Systems. 
(c)  Revenues. 
(1)  The revenues collected, as a result of the user charges levied, shall be deposited in a separate nonlapsing fund known as the sewer general fund, and shall pass through to two other nonlapsing funds designed as sewer operation and maintenance fund, and the sewer repair and replacement fund. 
(2)  Fiscal year-end balances in the operation and maintenance fund, and the sewer repairs and replacement fund shall be used for no other purposes than those designated. Monies which have been transferred from other sources to meet temporary shortages in the operation, maintenance and replacement fund shall be returned to their respective accounts upon appropriate adjustment of the user charge rates for operation, maintenance and replacement. The user charge rate(s) shall be adjusted such that the transferred monies will be returned to their respective accounts within six months of the fiscal year in which the monies were borrowed. 
(d)  The following schedule of user charge rates shall apply to each user of the wastewater treatment works. This schedule includes rates for OM&R and rates for debt service charges, each based on the volume of metered or estimated water consumption.
