Chapter 10 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Loitering, KRS 525.090; public intoxication, KRS 525.100; pornography, KRS 531.010 et seq; crimes and punishments, KRS ch. 431 et seq.; state penal code, KRS ch. 500 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Attaching advertising to poles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to nail, paste, clip, tie or fasten any bill, poster, placard, candidate card, or advertisement upon any telephone, telegraph or electricity pole or any other pole or post, tree or tree guard located on the street right-of-way or thoroughfare of the city, or upon proper under the control and jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-12-57, § 2) 
Cross reference- Signs, Ch. 13.5; placing handbills in vehicles, § 16-3. 
State Law reference- Unlawfully posting advertising, KRS 512.080. 
Sec. 10-2. - Wearing masks prohibited in public places. 
(a)  Definition. As used in this section, the term "public place" includes all walks, alleys, streets, boulevards, avenues, lanes, roads, highways, or other ways of thoroughfare dedicated to public use or owned or maintained by public authority. 
(b)  Prohibition in public places. No person shall, while wearing any hood, mask, or device whereby a substantial portion of the face is hidden or covered so as to conceal the identity of the wearer, enter, be or appear in any public place within the city. 
(c)  Prohibition on the property of another. No person shall, while wearing any hood, mask, or device whereby a substantial portion of the face is hidden or covered so as to conceal the identity of the wearer, demand entrance or admission, enter or come upon or into, or be upon or in the premises, enclosure or house of any other person in the city unless such person shall have first obtained the written permission of the owner and the occupant of such property. 
(d)  Exemptions. The following are exempted from the provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of this section: 
(1)  Any person under 16 years of age; 
(2)  Any person wearing traditional holiday costumes in season; 
(3)  Any person using masks in theatrical productions, including use in mardi gras celebrations and masquerade balls; 
(4)  Any person lawfully engaged in trades or employment or in a sporting activity where a mask or facial covering is worn for the purpose of ensuring the physical safety of the wearer, or because of the nature of the occupation, trade or professional or sporting activity; 
(5)  Any person wearing a gas mask in drills, exercises or emergencies. 
(Ord. of 10-27-80, §§ 1-4) 
Sec. 10-3. - Returned check fee; Bad check list. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed a $25.00 collection fee on all checks returned by the bank for insufficient funds or closed accounts. 
(b)  Upon return of the second check for insufficient funds or closed account, the check writer's name will be placed on the bad check list maintained in the office of the city clerk and no further checks will be accepted from the individual. 
(Ord. No. 13-85, §§ 1, 2, 12-9-85; Ord. No. 15-07, 11-5-07) 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of nonamendatory Ord. No. 13-85, adopted Dec. 9, 1985, have been codified as § 10-3 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 10-4. - Yard sale regulations. 
(a)  There shall be no more than four yard sales per household within a one-year period, each sale lasting for no more than three consecutive days (24-hour periods) at a time. 
(b)  Any display of merchandise in a yard, driveway, garage, carport, parking lot or vacant lot, covered or uncovered shall not be permitted outside the scope of the ordinances regulating yard sales, regardless of whether a sign is being displayed or sales are actually taking place. 
(c)  No yard sale shall be permitted, nor shall merchandise be stored, other than in a permitted enclosed structure, for a period of time exceeding three consecutive days (24-hour periods), and then no more than four times in a one-year period. 
(d)  Outdoor special sales events. Occasional outdoor special sales events involving items typically found at a yard, garage, carport or rummage sale are allowed in all zones, with the exception of R-1, R-2, and R-3, with an outdoor special sales event permit available free of charge from the office of planning, building and code enforcement. The permit shall be obtained at least two business days prior to the event. Typical items to be sold at such events include, but are not limited to household items, antiques, rare items, used clothes, used books, etc. Such events are to be limited to four times per year at any one location. Each event may last no longer than 48 consecutive hours. 
    Exempted from this subsection are peddlers selling fruits, vegetables and other agricultural or organic products and sales sponsored by the Mayfield-Graves County Parks and Recreation Board, Inc. (i.e. weekly monday trade days). 
    All merchandise shall be displayed in an orderly manner and shall be removed within 24 hours of the end of the sales event. The site of the sale shall be clear of any left over merchandise, litter, and must be returned to pre-sale condition or better. Failure to do so will result in a citation for criminal littering. 
    Those holding these outdoor special sales events must have written permission from the property owner. Regulations regarding parking, adequate entrances and exits will be enforced by city staff. Staff may cause such sales events to cease if safety concerns are evident. 
(e)  Signs advertising yard sales are not to be placed in the public right of way as to not pose a sight visibility problem. Such signs must be removed within eight hours of the conclusion of the sale. In the event that city staff must remove the signs from the right of way and/or remove them after the lawful conclusion of the sale, a fine of not less than $100.00 will be assessed to the person conducting the sale. In addition, it is considered unlawful to attach any such yard or garage sale sign to any traffic control sign or device, or utility pole or street sign in the city. A criminal penalty of not less than $250.00 will be assessed to anyone placing a sign on a traffic control sign or device, or utility pole or street sign in the city. 
(Ord. No. 6-91, 10-1-91; Ord. No. 15-92, §§ II, III, 5-11-92; Ord. No. 2-10, § 1, 3-8-10; Ord. No. 1-14, § 1, 2-10-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6-91, adopted Oct. 1, 1991, as amended by Ord. No. 15-92, adopted May 11, 1992 and Ord. No. 2-10, adopted Mar. 8, 2010, has been included herein at the discretion of the editor as § 10-4. 
Cross reference- Yard sale signs, § 13.5-3(b)(5). 
Secs. 10-5-10-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HOUSING DISCRIMINATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Human rights commission, § 2-40 et seq. 

Sec. 10-20. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    Discrimination: Any direct or indirect act or practice of exclusion, distinction, restriction, segregation, limitation, refusal, denial or any other act or practice of differentiation or preference in the treatment of a person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, or age between 40 and 65, or the aiding, abetting, inciting, coercing or compelling thereof. 
    Financial institution: Bank, banking organization, mortgage company, insurance company, or other lender to whom application is made for financial assistance for the purchase, lease, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair, maintenance, or improvement of real property, or an individual employed by or acting on behalf of any of these. 
    Housing accommodations: Includes improved and unimproved property and means a building, structure, lot or part thereof which is used or occupied, or is intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as the home or residence of one or more individuals. 
    Real estate broker or real estate salesman: An individual, whether licensed or not, who, on behalf of others, for a fee, commission, salary, or other valuable consideration, or who with the intention or expectation of receiving or collecting the same, lists, sells, purchases, exchanges, rents or leases real estate, or the improvements thereon, including options, or who negotiates or attempts to negotiate on behalf of others such an activity; or who advertises or holds such person's self out as engaged in such activities; or who negotiates or attempts to negotiate on behalf of others a loan secured by mortgage or other encumbrance upon a transfer of real estate, or who is engaged in business of charging an advance fee or contracting for collection of a fee in connection with a contract whereby such person undertakes to promote the sale, purchase, exchange, rental, or lease of real estate through a listing in a publication issued primarily for such purpose; or an individual employed by or acting on behalf of any of these. 
    Real estate operator: Any individual or combination of individuals, labor unions, joint apprenticeship committees, partnerships, associations, corporations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint-stock companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers or other legal or commercial entity, the county or any of its agencies, that is engaged in the business of selling, purchasing, exchanging, renting or leasing real estate, derives income, in whole or in part, from the sale, purchase, exchange, rental or lease of real estate; or an individual employed by or acting on behalf of any of these. 
    Real property: Includes buildings, structures, real estate, lands, tenements, leaseholds, cooperatives, condominiums, and hereditaments, corporeal and incorporeal, or any interest in the above. 
(Ord. of 6-12-78, Art. I, §§ 2-7) 
Sec. 10-21. - Unlawful housing practices-Enumerated. 
    It is an unlawful practice for a real estate operator, or for a real estate broker, real estate salesman, or an individual employed by or acting on behalf of any of those: 
(1)  To refuse to sell, exchange, rent or lease, or to otherwise deny to or withhold, real property from an individual because of such individual's race, color, religion, or national origin; 
(2)  To discriminate against an individual because of such individual's race, color, religion, or national origin in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the sale, exchange, rental or lease of real property or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith; 
(3)  To refuse to receive or transmit a bona fide offer to purchase, rent or lease real property from an individual because of such individual's race, color, religion, or national origin; 
(4)  To refuse to negotiate for the sale, rental or lease of real property to an individual because of such individual's race, color, religion, or national origin; 
(5)  To represent to an individual that real property is not available for inspection, sale, rental, or lease when in fact it is so available, or to refuse to permit an individual to inspect real property because of such individual's race, color, religion or national origin; 
(6)  To print, circulate, post or mail or cause to be printed, circulated, posted or mailed an advertisement or sign or to use a form of application for the purchase, rental or lease of real property, or to make a record of inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase, rental or lease of real property, which indicates, directly or indirectly, a limitation, specification, or discrimination as to race, color, religion or national origin or an intent to make such a limitation, specification, or discrimination; 
(7)  To offer, solicit, accept, use or retain a listing of real property for sale, rental or lease with the understanding that an individual may be discriminated against in the sale, rental or lease of that real property or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith because of such individual's race, color, religion, national origin; or 
(8)  To otherwise deny to or withhold real property from an individual because of such individual's race, color, religion or national origin. 
(Ord. of 6-12-78, Art. II, § 1) 
Sec. 10-22. - Same-Exemptions. 
    Nothing in section 10-21 shall apply: 
(1)  To the rental of housing accommodations in a building which contains housing accommodations for not more than two families living independently of each other, if the owner or a member of the owner's family resides in one of the housing accommodations; 
(2)  To the rental of a portion of a housing accommodation by the occupant of the housing accommodation, or by the owner of the housing accommodations if the owner or a member of the owner's family resides therein; 
(3)  To a religious institution, or to an organization operated for charitable or educational purposes, which is operated, supervised or controlled by a religious corporation, association, or society, to the extent that the religious corporation, association, or society, limits, or gives preferences in, the sale, lease, rental, assignment, or sublease of real property to individuals of the same religion, or makes a selection of buyers, tenants, lessees, assignees, or sublessees, that is calculated by such religious corporation, association, or society, limits, or gives preferences in, the sale, lease, rental, assignment, or sublease of real property to individuals of the same religion, or makes a selection of buyers, tenants, lessees, assignees, or sublessees, that is calculated by such religious corporation, association, or society to promote the religious principles for which it is established or maintained; 
(4)  To the private sale by a private individual homeowner who disposes of such owner's property without the aid of any real estate operator, broker or salesman and without advertising or public display; or 
(5)  To a real estate operator to require such operator to negotiate with any individual who has not shown evidence of financial ability to consummate the purchase or rental of a housing accommodation. 
(Ord. of 6-12-78, Art. II, § 2) 
Sec. 10-23. - Unlawful financial practices. 
    It is an unlawful practice for a financial institution or an individual employed by or acting on behalf of a financial institution: 
(1)  To discriminate against an individual because of the race, color, religion, or national origin of the individual or the present or prospective owner, tenant or occupant of the real property or of a member, stockholder, director, officer, employee, or representative of any of these, in the granting, withholding, extending, modifying or renewing, the rates, terms, conditions, privileges or other provisions of financial assistance or in the extension of services in connection therewith; or 
(2)  To use a form of application for financial assistance or to make or keep a record or inquiry in connection with applications for financial assistance which indicate directly or indirectly a limitation, specification, or discrimination. 
(Ord. of 6-12-78, Art. III, § 3) 
Sec. 10-24. - Blockbusting. 
    It is an unlawful practice for a real estate operator, a real estate broker, a real estate salesman, a financial institution, an employee of any of these, or any other person, for the purpose of inducing a real estate transaction from which any such person may benefit financially: 
(1)  To represent that a change has occurred or will or may occur in the composition with respect to race, color, religion or national origin of the owners or occupants in the block, neighborhood, or area in which the real property is located; or 
(2)  To represent that this change will or may result in the lowering of property values, an increase in criminal or antisocial behavior, or a decline in the quality of schools in the block, neighborhood, or area in which the real property is located. 
(Ord. of 6-12-78, Art. II, § 4) 
Sec. 10-25. - Agency no defense. 
    It shall be no defense to a violation of this article by a real estate operator, real estate broker, real estate salesman, financial institution, or other person subject to the provisions of this article that the violation was requested, sought or otherwise procured by a person not subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-12-78, Art. II, § 5) 
Secs. 10-26-10-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-96, §§ 1-6, adopted Aug. 12, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as Art. III, §§ 10-41-10-46, of this chapter was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 10-41. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this article: 
    Allow: To either permit or neglect to refrain or prevent. On the part of a parent or other guardian (as defined in this section), it requires actual or constructive knowledge, that is the person must actually know about the minor violating this article, or the circumstances must be such that a reasonable person should have known that the minor was violating this article. 
    Minor: Any person under the age of 18 years or, otherwise phrased, any person aged 17 or younger. 
    Parent: Any person having legal custody of a minor: 
(1)  As a natural or adoptive parent; 
(2)  As a legal guardian; 
(3)  As a person who stands "in loco parentis"; 
(4)  As a person who has been given legal custody by court order. 
    Remain: To stay behind, to tarry, or to stay unnecessarily upon or in any place of public assembly, building, place, street, highway, sidewalk, alleyway, or premises. 
(Ord. No. 12-96, § 1, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 10-42. - Curfew hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor to remain upon or in any place of public assembly, building, place, street, highway, sidewalk, alleyway, or premises within the city during the following times: 
1:00 a.m. Saturday to 6:00 a.m. Saturday; 
1:00 a.m. Sunday to 6:00 a.m. Sunday; 
11:00 p.m. Sunday to 6:00 a.m. Monday; 
11:00 p.m. Monday to 6:00 a.m. Tuesday; 
11:00 p.m. Tuesday to 6:00 a.m. Wednesday; 
11:00 p.m. Wednesday to 6:00 a.m. Thursday; 
11:00 p.m. Thursday to 6:00 a.m. Friday. 
    The hours of 11:00 p.m. above shall be changed to 12:00 midnight during times of the year when the regular school year is not in effect. 
(Ord. No. 12-96, § 2, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 10-43. - Parental responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian having legal custody of a minor to allow such minor to be or remain upon or in any place of public assembly, building, place, street, highway, sidewalk, alleyway, or premises within the city under circumstances not constituting an exception as enumerated in section 10-44 during the time periods contained in section 10-42. 
(Ord. No. 12-96, § 3, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 10-44. - Exceptions to curfew. 
    In the following exceptional cases, a minor in any place of public assembly, building, place, street, highway, sidewalk, alleyway or premises within the city shall not be considered in violation of section 10-42: 
(1)  When the minor is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian; 
(2)  When accompanied by an adult 21 years of age or older who is authorized by the parent or legal guardian; 
(3)  When exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly, provided that prior written notice has been given to the mayor of the city and signed by the minor and countersigned by the parent or legal guardian and is in the possession of such minor specifying when, where, and in what manner said minor will be exercising such First Amendment rights; 
(4)  If the child is coming directly from an organized school activity or an organized activity of a religious or other voluntary association, or a place of public entertainment such as a movie, play, concert, or sporting event. This will apply to one-half hour after the completion of such event, but in no case beyond 30 minutes after the curfew time for that particular day; 
(5)  If the child is on a legitimate errand for the parent or legal guardian; 
(6)  If the minor is legally employed by a legitimate business, one-half hour before to one-half hour after scheduled work hours, while going directly between his/her home and place of employment; 
(7)  If the minor is on the property of his/her own residence or property directly adjacent to this residence, with the permission of the owner of the adjacent property, and is causing no problems such as interfering with the comfort of those in or passing through the area; 
(8)  When the minor is lawfully operating a motor vehicle or, with parental knowledge and consent, is a passenger in a motor vehicle with a lawfully authorized driver for the purpose of passing through, by direct route, from one location to another either within or out of the city. 
(9)  When an actual emergency exists which requires that the minor be out. 
(Ord. No. 12-96, § 4, 8-12-96; Ord. No. 20-96, § 1, 9-9-96) 
Sec. 10-45. - Determination of violation. 
    A police officer who suspects that a minor is in violation of this article shall determine whether or not the minor is in violation. This is to be accomplished by the officer asking the minor to provide his/her name, proof of age, address, and the name and phone number of the parent/guardian. If probable cause exists, the minor shall accompany the officer to the police station where the child's parent/guardian shall immediately be contacted. If it is still determined that the minor is in violation of the article, the child shall be held until the parent/guardian comes to take the child home. When the parent/guardian arrives he shall be advised of this article and may be written a citation requiring appearance in Graves District Court. If, after two hours, no one has come to pick up the child, the Cabinet for Human Resources, Division of Social Services shall be contacted and told of the situation so that action can be taken through that agency. 
(Ord. No. 12-96, § 5, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 10-46. - Penalty. 
    In the case of a first violation by a minor, when no other violations of law are involved, the police shall provide the parent/guardian with written notice of the violation, warning them that further violations shall result in a citation requiring their appearance in Graves District Court where a penalty may be assessed on them, a fine of up to $500.00. Any minor who violates the ordinance more than three times shall be charged in juvenile court with being beyond parental control. 
(Ord. No. 12-96, § 6, 8-12-96)

ARTICLE V. - PROHIBITION OF PORNOGRAPHY 

Sec. 10-70. - Definitions. 
    Distribute means to transfer possession of, with or without consideration. 
    Matter means any book, magazine, newspaper, or other printed or written material or any picture, drawing, photograph, motion picture, or other pictorial representation or any statue or other figure, any recording transcription or mechanical, chemical or electrical reproduction or any other articles, equipment, machines or materials. 
    Obscene means 
(1)  To the average person, applying contemporary community standards, the predominant appeal of the "matter" taken as a whole, is to prurient interest in sexual conduct, and 
(2)  The "matter" depicts or describes the sexual conduct in an obviously offensive way, and 
(3)  The "matter" taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value. 
    Sexual conduct means acts of homosexuality, lesbianism, bestiality, masturbation, sexual intercourse, deviant sexual intercourse, physical contact with the genitals, flagellation, or excretion for the purpose of sexual stimulation or gratification. 
(Ord. No. 12-99, § I, 9-13-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, KRS 531.010. 
Sec. 10-71. - Obscene matters. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person having knowledge of "obscene matters" content and character to: 
(1)  Send or cause it to be sent into the city for sale or distribution. 
(2)  Bring or cause it to be brought into the city for sale or distribution. 
(3)  To prepare, publish, print, exhibit, distribute, offer to distribute it or have in one's possession with the intent to distribute. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person a person within the city knowing a person to be a minor, or having such facts that they should reasonably know that such person is a minor, and with knowledge of the content and character of the matter to be obscene to; send or cause to be sent, exhibit, or distribute or offer to distribute obscene matter to a minor. 
(Ord. No. 12-99, §§ II, III, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 10-72. - Violations. 
    The penalty for a violation of section 10-71 of this article shall be the same as that specified in K.R.S. 531.020(2). 
    The penalty for a violation of section 10-71 of this article shall be the same as that specified in K.R.S. 531.030(2). 
(Ord. No. 12-99, §§ IV, V, 9-13-99) 
Secs. 10-73-10-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PURPOSE, DEFINITIONS, PROHIBITIONS AND PENALTY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1-12, §§ 1-4, adopted March 12, 2012, was not specifically amendatory. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Article VI, §§ 10-90-10-93. 

Sec. 10-90. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this ordinance is to stop the possession or sale of AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids and HU cannabinoids. These substances are harmful if consumed and present a significant public health danger that can result in hospitalization or death. 
(Ord. No. 1-12, § 1, 3-12-12) 
Sec. 10-91. - Definitions. 
    AM cannabinoids means any synthetic cannabinoids created by Alexandros Makriyannis or his research group including but not limited to AM-087; AM-251; AM-281; AM-356; AM-374; AM-381; AM-404; AM-411; AM-630; AM-661; AM-678; AM-679; AM-694; AM-855; AM-881; AM-883; AM-905; AM-906; AM-919; AM-926; AM-938; AM-1116; AM-1172; AM-1220; AM-1221; AM-1235; AM-1241; AM-1248; AM-2201; AM-2212; AM-2213; AM-2232; AM-2233; AM-2102; AM-4030. The term shall not include synthetic cannabinoids that require a prescription, are approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration, and are dispensed in accordance with state and federal law. 
    CP cannabinoids means CP-47,497; (C6)-CP-47,497; (C7)-CP-47,497; (C8)-CP-47,497; (C9)-CP-47,497; CP-50,556-1; CP-55,244; CP-55,940; CP-945,598. The term shall not include synthetic cannabinoids that require a prescription, are approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration, and are dispensed in accordance with state and federal law. 
    HU cannabinoids means any synthetic cannabinoids synthesized at the Hebrew University including but not limited to HU-210; HU-211; HU-243; HU-308; HU-320; HU-331; HU-336; HU-345. The term shall not include synthetic cannabinoids that require a prescription, are approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration, and are dispensed in accordance with state and federal law. 
    JWH cannabinoids means any synthetic cannabinoids created by John W. Huffman or his research group including but not limited to JWH-007; JWH-015; JWH-018; JWH-019; JWH-030; JWH-047; JWH-048; JWH-051; JWH-057; JWH-073; JWH-081; JWH-098; JWH-116; JWH-120; JWH-122; JWH-133; JWH-139; JWH-147; JWH-148; JWH-149; JWH-161; JWH-164; JWH-166; JWH-167; JWH-171; JWH-175; JWH-176; JWH-181; JWH-182; JWH-184; JWH-185; JWH-192; JWH-193; JWH-194; JWH-195; JWH-196; JWH-197; JWH-198; JWH-199; JWH-200; JWH-203; JWH-205; JWH-210; JWH-213; JWH-229; JWH-234; JWH-249; JWH-250; JWH-251; JWH-253; JWH-258; JWH-300; JWH-302; JWH-307; JWH-336; JWH-350; JWH-359; JWH-387; JWH-398; JWH-424. The term shall not include synthetic cannabinoids that require a prescription, are approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration, and are dispensed in accordance with state and federal law. 
    Person means individual, corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership or association, or any other legal entity. 
    Possession means to have actual physical possession or otherwise to exercise actual dominion or control over a tangible object; 
    Traffic means to manufacture, distribute, dispense, sell, transfer, or possess with intent to manufacture, distribute, dispense, or sell a controlled substance. 
    Transfer means to dispose of a controlled substance to another person without consideration and not in furtherance of commercial distribution. 
(Ord. No. 1-12, § 2, 3-12-12) 
Sec. 10-92. - Prohibition of possession or sale of AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids. 
(a)  Trafficking in AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids . 
    A person is guilty of trafficking in AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids when he or she knowingly and unlawfully traffics in AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids. 
(b)  Possession of AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids . 
    A person is guilty of possession of AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids when he or she knowingly and unlawfully possesses AM cannabinoids, CP cannabinoids, JWH cannabinoids or HU cannabinoids. 
Ord. No. 1-12, § 3, 3-12-12 
Sec. 10-93. - Penalty. 
    If current or future Kentucky law(s) (KRS, etc.) prohibits any substance(s) contained in this article, the Kentucky law(s) (KRS, etc.) shall be applied instead of this article for both prosecution and penalty. 
(1)  Trafficking in marijuana. 
a.  Trafficking in less than eight ounces of marijuana is: 
1.  For a first offense a class A misdemeanor. 
2.  For a second or subsequent offense a class D felony. 
b.  Trafficking in eight or more ounces but less than five pounds of marijuana is: 
1.  For a first offense a class D felony. 
2.  For a second or subsequent offense a class C felony. 
c.  Trafficking in five or more pounds of marijuana is: 
1.  For a first offense a class C felony. 
2.  For a second or subsequent offense a class B felony. 
d.  The unlawful possession by any person of eight or more ounces of marijuana shall be prima facie evidence that the person possessed the marijuana with the intent to sell or transfer it. 
(2)  Possession of marijuana. Possession of marijuana is a class B misdemeanor, except that, KRS ch. 532 to the contrary notwithstanding, the maximum term of incarceration shall be no greater than 45 days. 
(Ord. No. 1-12, § 4, 3-12-2012; Ord. No. 35-17, § I, 11-13-17) 
Chapter 11 - PARKS AND RECREATION 

Sec. 11-1. - Mayfield-Graves County Park Board. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board to be known as the Mayfield-Graves County Park Board. 
(b)  The board shall consist of seven members, to include the mayor of this city, county judge, county school superintendent, city school superintendent, one county commissioner, one council member of this city, one minority member to be appointed by the county judge and the mayor; city councilmember appointed by mayor, county commissioner appointed by county judge. 
(c)  Each member shall serve for a term of four years; provided, however, that the terms of the members shall be staggered. In order to stagger the terms of members, three members, specifically the minority member, councilmember and commissioner, shall be appointed for a term of two years; the remaining four members shall be appointed for a term of four years. Thereafter, all terms to membership shall be for terms of four years. All board members shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for any necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. Vacancies in the board membership shall be filled for unexpired terms by the appointment of the authority appointing the member whose office is vacant. 
(d)  The board shall be a body corporate for all purposes and shall elect from its membership a chairman, vice chairman, secretary and treasurer. The treasurer shall execute a bond, conditioned on the faithful performance of such duties, sufficient in amount to cover the funds coming into such officer's hands. The premium on such bond shall be paid from the board funds. 
(e)  The board shall possess all powers and duties as provided in KRS ch. 97. 
(f)  The fiscal court of the county shall likewise approve the authority set out in KRS ch. 97 for the joint establishment of a Mayfield-Graves County Park Board. 
(g)  Subject to the approval of the city council and the fiscal court of the county, the board shall enact such bylaws and amendments as are necessary to maintain and conduct the business of the recreation system; however, no bylaws or amendments shall be enacted by said board that will conflict with, or negate this section. The board shall also enact such rules and regulations as are necessary to maintain and conduct the business of the recreation system without the approval of the city council and the fiscal court of the county. 
(Ord. of 2-14-77, § 2) 
State Law reference- Authority to create park board, KRS 97.550. 
Sec. 11-2. - Applicability of chapter-"Public parks" defined. 
    The rules and regulations hereinafter prescribed shall govern the public parks of the city. "Public parks" for the purpose of this chapter shall include all dedicated parks maintained by the city. 
(Ord. No. 24-17, § I, 7-10-17) 
Sec. 11-3. - Prohibited conduct generally. 
    Within the limits of any said park, it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to do any of the acts hereinafter specified: 
(1)  To discharge any firearms, firecrackers, rockets, or any other fireworks, air guns or slingshots. 
(2)  To cut, break, injure, deface or disturb any tree, shrub, plant, rock, building, monument, fence, bench or other structures, apparatus or property; or to pull up, cut, take or remove any shrub or bush; or to mark or write upon, paint or deface in any manner, any building, monument, fence, bench or other structure. 
(3)  To leave garbage, cans, bottles, paper or other refuse elsewhere than in the receptacles provided. 
(4)  To indulge in riotous, boisterous, threatening or indecent conduct, or abusive, threatening, profane or indecent language or indecent clothing. 
(5)  To post or erect any bill, notice, paper, circular or advertising or display of any kind, except as approved in conjunction with an event for which a permit has been approved pursuant to this chapter. 
(6)  To sell or offer for sale any merchandise, article or thing, whatsoever, without first obtaining a permit from the planning and community development department to do so. 
(7)  To remain, stay or loiter in any public park between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(8)  To possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in any public park. "Alcoholic beverage" is defined as any beverage defined as an alcoholic beverage by the Alcoholic Beverage Control Laws and Administrative Regulations of the Commonwealth of Kentucky. 
(9)  No company, society, church or organization of more than 25 persons shall hold or conduct any picnic, celebration, parade, service or exercise in any public park, without first obtaining a permit from the planning and community development department and it shall be unlawful for any person to take part in any picnic, celebration, parade, service or exercise held or conducted contrary to the provisions hereof. 
(10)  No inflatables, carnival rides, or portable games shall be allowed in any of the public parks without a permit, under specified circumstances, from the department of planning and community development. 
(11)  No tents, pop-ups, or gazebos shall be erected in any public park without a permit from the department of planning and community development. 
(12)  All dogs within any of the city parks will be required to be on leashes, and/or muzzled in accordance with the city dog ordinance. All animal feces shall be removed and placed in garbage containers or other receptacles provided for same. 
(13)  Regarding activities where a permit is required, the permit holder shall have the permit available for inspection by city authorities. 
(Ord. No. 24-17, § I, 7-10-17)

ARTICLE II. - DRUG AND ALCOHOL POLICIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-11, adopted November 14, 2011, repealed §§ 12-21-12-32 in their entirety. Formerly §§ 12-12-12-32, pertained to personnel policies and procedures and were derived from Ord. No. 13-90, adopted June 26, 1990; Ord. No. 17-92, adopted April 13, 1992; Ord. No. 3-96, adopted February 12, 1996; and Ord. No. 25-03, adopted December 12, 2004. 

Sec. 12-21. - Drug and alcohol testing program. 
(a)  Statement of purpose. 
(1)  Introduction. The purpose of this drug and alcohol test policy is to intervene with employees who may be working in an impaired condition or under the influence that may harm themselves, fellow employees, the public, or the city. "Drug or alcohol induced impairment" or "under the influence" under this policy includes impairment as a result of: (a) over-the-counter drugs; (b) prescribed drugs; (c) illegal drugs; or (d) alcohol. 
(2)  Policy statement. It shall be the policy of the city that an employee found to be in the possession of, other than proper custodial control, under the influence of, impaired by, using, selling, offering for sale, or trading (whether or not for profit or pecuniary gain) drugs or alcohol during working hours or on city property will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including immediate discharge. Nothing contained in this policy shall make an employee subject to discipline for mere possession of an over-the-counter drug or prescribed drug for an employee. The city recognizes that drug and alcohol abuse may be illnesses for which treatment and rehabilitation programs are available. All employees shall be provided a copy of this policy and procedure. The policy will initially be posted on all employee bulletin boards. 
(b)  Definitions. 
    Accident will be defined as physical injury to one's self requiring medical treatment other than normal first aid, damage to property owned by the city, physical injury to others requiring medical treatment due to the incident and/or physical damage to property not owned by the city due to the incident. 
    Alcohol means any liquid that has an alcoholic content in excess of one percent by volume. 
    CDL employee means any employee who has a commercial motor vehicle operator's license. 
    Candidate means any individual tentatively selected for full-time employment with the city; may also be referred to as job applicant. 
    Drug means any substance (other than alcohol) capable of altering the mood, perception, pain level, or judgment of the individual consuming it. 
    Drug and alcohol testing program coordinator (DATPC) refers to the individual, appointed by the mayor, responsible for the overall management and administration of this policy within the city under the general supervision and direction of the mayor. 
    Drug and alcohol testing facility (DATF) refers to firms and associated facilities selected by the city council to conduct the actual drug and alcohol testing, randomly select employees for testing and to otherwise assist the city in carrying out the requirements of this section. 
    EBT (evidential breath testing device) means an EBT approved by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) for the evidential testing of breath and placed on NHTSA's "Conforming Products List of Evidential Breath Measurement Devices" (CPL). 
    Employee means any part-time or full-time, hourly or salaried person that works directly for the city. 
    Employee assistance program (EAP) means a confidential counseling program established by the city to aid and assist city employees to correct a drug or alcohol problem and to monitor the progress of employees while in treatment and after-care. 
    Full-time employee means all hourly and salaried city personnel working at least 30 hours per week, and employed for at least 45 weeks per year. For the purposes of this section, this shall not also include part-time/seasonal employees. 
    He or his also means "she" or "hers" in appropriate context. 
    Illegal drug means any drug or controlled substance including, but not limited to, substances controlled or prohibited by federal or state law, the sale or possession of which is illegal. 
    Medical review officer (MRO) must be a licensed doctor of medicine (MD) or doctor of osteopathy (DO) and refers to the individual responsible for interpreting drug and alcohol test results who has knowledge of alcohol and substance abuse disorders and the appropriate medical training to interpret and evaluate all positive drug and alcohol screens together with an employee's medical history and any other relevant biomedical information. 
    Non-sensitive position means a job position of the city where the nature of the position does not involve any safety sensitive and other sensitive functions. These positions are specifically excluded from initial testing, random testing, post-accident testing, and return-to-duty testing. These positions shall include but are not limited to: the city custodian, administrative assistant to planning/public works department, and part-time/seasonal employees. 
    Other sensitive position shall be a job position of the city, other than a safety sensitive position where the nature of the duties involve the potential mismanagement or loss of monetary resources and/or misuse or disclosure of confidential and personal information and where the influence of alcohol or drugs may significantly increase the risk of mismanagement or loss. Examples include: full-time employees working in the city clerk's offices, the mayor's executive assistant, and the administrative assistant to the public safety department. 
    Part-time or seasonal employee means an employee that is employed less than 30 hours a week or for less than 45 weeks cumulatively during any calendar year. 
    Positive alcohol screen means positive identification of an alcohol concentration of 0.02 or greater for CDL employees and 0.04 or greater for all other employees, has been confirmed by the testing procedure described herein. Only an alcohol concentration level of 0.04 or greater is subject to disciplinary action for all employees, including CDL employees. 
    Positive drug screen means positive identification of an illegal drug which has been confirmed by the testing procedures described herein. Another positive drug screen may be the positive identification of a legal drug to include a prescribed drug which may otherwise impair or affect the ability of an employee to properly and safely perform his/her job. Concentration levels of marijuana, cocaine, opiates, amphetamines, phencyclides, shall be as set forth in CFR 49, Part 40 to indicate a positive drug screen. No other minimum concentration levels for drugs shall be established, meaning that any detectable amount of another drug will constitute a positive drug screen. 
    Prescribed drug means any substance prescribed for the individual consuming it by a licensed medical practitioner. 
    Random testing means a system of drug testing imposed without reasonable suspicion in which the designated employee to be tested is selected from a statistically random sampling of all employees, or in the case of CDL employees, a designated group of employees. 
    Reasonable suspicion means an articulable belief which is based on specific facts and reasonable inferences drawn from those facts that an employee is under the influence of drugs or alcohol. 
    Reasonable suspicion testing means a test where an employee will be tested when there is a reasonable suspicion that the employee is under the influence of drugs or alcohol. 
    Refusal to consent to a drug and alcohol test means the failure of any employee or candidate to sign a drug and alcohol testing consent form or the failure of the employee or candidate to follow through as directed for the proper completion of a drug and alcohol test. 
    Safety sensitive position means a job position of the city where the nature of the position involves the potential for damage to property and injury or loss of life in the performance of those duties and where the influence of alcohol and/or drugs may significantly increase the risk of damage to property and/or injury or loss of life. Examples include: All police officers, dispatchers, fire fighters, emergency rescue personnel, fire inspectors, code enforcement officers, building official, and public works employees. 
    SAP (substance abuse professional) means this individual is responsible for determining what assistance, if any, the employee needs in resolving problems associated with alcohol and drug use, and must be knowledgeable about and have clinical experience in the diagnosis and treatment of both drug and alcohol-related disorders (must be a licensed physician, either a medical doctor (MD) or doctor of osteopathy (DO), or a licensed or certified psychologist, social worker, employee assistance professional, or addiction counselor who is certified by the National Association of Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Counselors Certification Commission. 
(c)  General requirements. 
(1)  City employees shall not take or be under the influence of any narcotics or dangerous substance unless prescribed by the employees' licensed physician. Employees who are required to take prescription medicine should notify their immediate supervisors of the medication prescribed and the nature of the illness or injury. 
(2)  City employees are prohibited from the possession, use and sale of drugs, alcohol or any other controlled substance on city property or in city vehicles. 
(3)  All property belonging to the city is subject to inspection at any time without notice as there is no expectation of privacy. 
a.  Property includes, but is not limited to vehicles, desks, containers, files, and storage lockers. 
b.  Employees assigned lockers (that are locked by the employee) are also subject to inspection by the employee's supervisor after reasonable advance notice (unless waived by the mayor) and in the presence of the employee. 
(4)  City employees who have reason to believe another employee is illegally using drugs or narcotics, shall report the facts and circumstances immediately to their supervisor. 
(5)  Failure to comply with the intent or provisions of this policy may be used as grounds for disciplinary action, including dismissal. 
(6)  All employee positions are subject to random drug testing as outlined in this policy. All drug-testing information will be maintained in separate confidential files. 
(d)  Prescriptions. 
(1)  Prescription and over-the-counter drugs are not prohibited when taken in standard dosage and/or according to a physician's prescription. However, any safety sensitive employee or employee with CDL, taking prescribed or over-the-counter medications will, in all cases, be responsible for consulting the prescribing physician and/or pharmacist to ascertain whether the medication may interfere with safe performance of his/her safety sensitive job duties. If, after the safety sensitive or CDL employee consults the prescribing physician or pharmacist, it is determined that the prescribed or over-the-counter medication may temporarily alter the employee's ability to perform their duties safely, it shall be the responsibility of the employee, prior to initiating usage, to submit a prescription drug notification form to their immediate supervisor who shall in turn, submit it to the city clerk or his/her authorized designee as soon as possible. 
(2)  After receiving such form, the city clerk, or his/her designee, may request written medical authorization showing the employee may possess/use such medication, that it was used in the prescribed manner and showing the employee is fit to safely perform their assigned duties. If the use of such medication could compromise the safety of the employee, fellow employees, or the public at large, it is the employee's responsibility to use appropriate personnel procedures (e.g., call in sick, use leave, request change of duty and notify his/her supervisor) to avoid unsafe workplace practices. No prescription drugs shall be brought onto city property, or consumed on city property by anyone other than the individual for whom the drugs have been prescribed by a licensed medical practitioner. The illegal or unauthorized use of prescription drugs is strictly prohibited. It is a violation of the city's drug-free workplace policy to intentionally misuse and/or abuse prescription medications. 
(3)  Appropriate disciplinary action will be taken if job performance deterioration and/or other accidents occur as the result of the intentional misuse and/or abuse of prescription medication. 
(4)  The city reserves the right to have a designated physician of the city's choosing to determine if a prescription drug or medication produces effects that would be considered unacceptable in the performance of assigned work duties. The city's physician has final determination on whether the medication will have or is having an unacceptable effect on the employee's performance of duties. In such instances of temporary impediment to safe performance of regular duties, the employee may be temporarily reassigned to duties requiring a lesser safety awareness level if such duties are available. 
(e)  Types of testing. 
(1)  Initial testing. During the first year of this policy, all employees who hold safety sensitive positions and other sensitive positions shall be required to undergo a drug and alcohol test arranged by the city. 
(2)  Pre-employment testing. All candidates for any position with the city shall be subject to a drug and alcohol test as described herein, excluding part-time/seasonal employees, only after a conditional offer of employment. 
(3)  Probationary employee testing. All probationary employees shall receive one additional drug test within 60 days prior to the end of the employee's probationary period. If a probationary employee is chosen for random testing during his or her probationary period it shall fulfill this requirement. 
(4)  Random testing. Since many city employees are in positions where the consequences of alcohol and drug use would be particularly damaging to said designated employee's safety, the safety of other employees, the security of sensitive information, or monies handled by the city, the general public and citizenry of Mayfield, or which may otherwise result in significant property loss or damage, unscheduled drug testing shall be utilized for safety sensitive and other sensitive positions. 
a.  Method of random testing. Every employee holding a safety sensitive or other sensitive position, excluding CDL employees, shall be assigned a number at random by the DATPC who shall keep said list of names and numbers confidential and on file in his office. Once during every three-month period, (January-March, etc.), the DATPC or DATF shall select approximately ten percent of city employees at random for drug and alcohol testing by a computerized random drawing from a pool consisting of all employee numbers excluding CDL employees. 
b.  CDL employees. Every CDL employee shall be assigned a number at random by the DATPC or DATF, who shall keep said list of names and numbers confidential and on file in his office. The CDL employees shall be placed in a separate pool from the other employees. During each calendar year, 50 percent of the average number of CDL employees for the year shall be selected by a computerized, random drawing, for a drug and alcohol test. This may be done in one testing event or several testing events. 
(5)  Reasonable cause/suspicion testing. Assistant department heads, department heads, mayor, or the DAPTC may require any employee to undergo drug and alcohol testing if there is a reasonable suspicion that the employee is under the influence of drugs or alcohol during working hours. An assistant department head shall require approval from their department head, the mayor, or the DAPTC to require such a test. Circumstances which constitute a basis for determining "reasonable suspicion" may include, but are not limited to: 
a.  A pattern of abnormal or erratic behavior; 
b.  Information provided by a reliable and credible source; 
c.  A work-related accident; 
d.  Direct observation of drug or alcohol use; or 
e.  Presence of the physical symptoms of drug or alcohol use (i.e., glassy or blood-shot eyes, alcohol odor on breath, slurred speech, poor coordination and/or reflexes). 
Whenever reasonable suspicion testing is proposed by an assistant department head, department head, mayor, or DAPTC, they shall be required to detail in writing the specific facts, symptoms, or observations which formed the basis for their determination that reasonable suspicion existed to warrant the testing of the employee. This documentation shall be forwarded to the appropriate department head and/or mayor. 
When a reasonable suspicion test is ordered, the employee must submit to testing within 45 minutes of being notified that he/she will be tested. The observing supervisor and/or designee shall remain at the testing site with the employee being tested, until the collection process is completed. Any employee who is tested for reasonable suspicion shall be placed on leave with pay until the results of the test are known. After submitting to the drug/alcohol test, the employee may not return to work until the results of the test are known and only then if the results are negative. 
In order to assist department heads and assistant department heads, the mayor and the DAPTC, in recognizing and detecting the symptoms of drug and alcohol use, they shall receive training in the determination of reasonable symptoms. 
(6)  Post-accident testing. 
a.  This section shall apply only to all employees holding safety sensitive and other sensitive positions. 
b.  Employees whose performance either contributed to an accident or cannot be completely discounted as a contributing factor to the accident or cannot be completely discounted as a contributing factor to the accident will be required to be tested. 
c.  Due to varying types of accident cause, all accidents categorized as a "qualifying event" may not require post-accident testing. Exceptions to the "qualifying event" for requiring post-accident drug and alcohol testing will include, but may not be limited to, the following types of accidents: 
1.  Injuries whose onset is cumulative or gradual - such as carpel tunnel syndrome, progressive hearing loss, mental disorders, dermatitis, respiratory diseases, skin disorders, etc. 
2.  Injuries where the employee can be completely discounted as the contributing factor (i.e. injuries caused by a third party or some other uncontrollable force or event, i.e. weather, insects, toxic plants, etc.) 
3.  Injuries where the employee can be completely discounted as the major contributing factor or those injuries occurring during physical fitness or a training event, in which the employee did everything within reason to avoid the injury accident, i.e. was performing training as instructed. 
d.  The employee will be tested as soon as possible, but not later than 32 hours after the accident. In the case where alcohol is suspected, such testing shall occur as soon as possible but in no case later than eight hours after the accident. 
e.  Accidents that occur while employee is not on city time are not subject to post-accident testing unless there is reason to believe that drug/alcohol misuse occurred and could have a direct effect on the employee's work behavior. 
f.  An employee involved in an accident while on an out-of-town assignment shall notify their department supervisor or the supervisor's designee as soon as possible but no later than two hours after the accident occurred. The department supervisor shall notify the mayor or his/her authorized designee to discuss possible drug/alcohol testing requirements. 
g.  All reasonable steps will be taken to obtain a urine sample from an employee after an accident. In case of a conscious but hospitalized employee, the hospital or medical facility will be required to obtain a sample and if necessary, reference will be made to DOT drug testing requirements. If an employee is unconscious or otherwise unable to evidence consent to the procedure, the medical facility shall collect the sample. 
h.  If a post-accident controlled substance/alcohol test is required, a confirmed positive test may result in the employee's immediate termination. 
(7)  Return to work testing. 
a.  This section shall only apply to all employees holding safety sensitive and other sensitive positions. 
b.  An employee who returns to work after being off for more than 30 days due to illness, work related accidents or leave of absence will be subject to testing. 
c.  An employee who returns to work after being disciplined for alcohol and/or drug abuse will be subjected to unannounced tests for a 12-month period following their return to work. These will be in addition to any of the other types of tests previously mentioned. A CDL employee must have a minimum of six tests in the first 12 months. 
In all cases, it shall be at the discretion of the city as to whether to allow an employee who has violated any provision of this policy to continue in the city's employment. In view of the fact that the use of illicit drugs is illegal, a positive test for non-prescribed controlled substances will result in the immediate termination of the employee testing positive. In the event that an employee, who has tested positive for alcohol without a valid medical reason for a positive test, as confirmed by a medical review officer of the city's choosing, is allowed to enter a controlled substance/alcohol abuse rehabilitation program, the employee may be allowed to return to work only under the following circumstances: 
1.  The employee may resume regular duties only after the employee tests negative in an alcohol test administered by the city-approved laboratory and can provide a release to return to work from an appropriate substance abuse treatment facility or confirmation of continued and on-going participation in a city-recognized alcohol abuse assistance program. 
2.  An employee must test negative within a reasonable period of time from receipt of the initial test results not to exceed 45 days. Any repeat occurrence of substance abuse or violation of any other aspect of the city's drug-free workplace policy will result in immediate termination. 
Prior to returning to work, the employee shall be required to meet with the mayor, city clerk and supervisor to receive an explanation of the terms of continued employment; and to sign a written treatment plan/return-to-work agreement, detailing the terms under which the employee will be allowed to return to work. Such agreement shall stipulate that the employee, at the city's request, may be required at any time to submit to interviews and/or evaluation by the professional staff at an appropriate chemical dependency treatment facility approved by the city's employee assistance program (EAP). The return-to-work agreement will also stipulate that the employee be required to submit to unannounced controlled substance and/or alcohol testing for up to 12 months after resuming duties. 
(8)  Other miscellaneous-type testing/checks. 
a.  A check of driver operators licenses and CDL licenses shall be made of any candidate for city employment for drug and alcohol related arrests/convictions. The same checks shall be made once annually for all full-time employees who may operate a city vehicle. Employees must sign the background check release form. 
b.  The employee shall have the responsibility for immediately notifying (within one week) his/her department head of any drug or alcohol-related arrests or convictions. 
(f)  Laboratory testing requirements. 
(1)  All drug and alcohol testing of employees and applicants shall be conducted at medical facilities or laboratories selected by the city. To be considered as a testing site, a medical facility or laboratory must submit in writing, a description of the procedure that will be used to maintain test samples. This submission will be maintained by the mayor or city clerk. Factors to be considered by the city in selecting a testing facility include: 
a.  Testing procedures which ensure privacy to employees and applicants consistent with the prevention of tampering; 
b.  Method of analysis which ensures reliable test results. Spectrometry to confirm positive and negative test results; 
c.  Chain-of-custody procedures which ensure proper identification, labeling, and handling of test samples; 
d.  Retention and storage procedures which ensure reliable results on confirmatory test of original samples. 
(2)  The testing for drugs/alcohol will be conducted in accordance with the outlines of the Controlled Substances Act and/or as outlined in 49 CFR Part 40, Procedures for Transportation Workplace Drug Testing Program. 
(3)  Testing is undertaken in three phases: collection agency, testing laboratory and medical review officer. All three shall be required to comply with all methods and procedures of 49 CFR Part 40 and will provide annual reports to the city showing compliance. The city may contract with one or more agencies and/or individuals to provide services to the city. 
(4)  Testing results will be released by the medical review officer to the mayor, the department head involved, and DATPC only. 
(5)  Addresses and phone numbers of the collection agency, testing laboratory, and medical review officer will be a part of this policy by reference. 
(g)  Consent to testing. 
(1)  Refusal to consent-Applicant/candidate. A job applicant who refuses to consent to a drug and alcohol test will be denied employment with the city. 
(2)  Refusal to consent-Employee. An employee who refuses to consent to a drug and alcohol test when reasonable suspicion of drug or alcohol use has been identified, or when required to undergo a test, is subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. The reason(s) for the refusal shall be considered in determining the appropriate disciplinary action. 
(h)  Confirmation of test results. 
(1)  An employee or job applicant whose drug test yields a positive result shall be given a second test. The second test shall use a portion of the same test sample withdrawn from the employee or applicant for use in the first test. 
(2)  If the second test confirms the positive test results, the medical review officer has the option to contact the employee/applicant for consultation on what medication he/she may be taking. Once the test has been confirmed by the medical review officer, a copy of the test results will be sent by phone and/or certified mail to the DATPC. The employee/applicant will then be notified by the city as to when and where to discuss the results of the test. 
(3)  An employee or applicant whose second test confirms the original positive test results may, at the employee's or applicant's own expense, have a third test conducted on the same sample at a laboratory selected by the city. 
(4)  Any negative test result (on test 1, 2, or 3) will constitute a negative test and all results will be destroyed. 
(i)  Positive test results. 
(1)  Consequences of a confirming positive test result-Job applicants/candidates. Job applicants/candidates will be denied employment with the city if their initial positive test results have been confirmed. Applicants shall be informed in writing if they are rejected on the basis of confirmed positive drug results. 
(2)  Consequences of a confirming positive test result-Employees. If a current employee's positive test result has been confirmed, the employee is subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. Factors to be considered in determining the appropriate disciplinary response include the employee's work history, length of employment, current job performance, and existence of past disciplinary actions. No disciplinary action may be taken against employees who voluntarily identify themselves as drug users prior to being notified of an impending drug and alcohol test, obtain counseling and rehabilitation through the city's employee assistance program or other programs sanctioned by the city and thereafter refrain from violating the city's policy on drug and alcohol abuse. 
(j)  Employee assistance program (EAP). 
(1)  If an employee has a positive drug screen or positive alcohol screen, and if the employee is not terminated, the employee shall be referred to the EAP. The EAP, designated by the city may, in turn, refer the employee to another organization which specializes in rehabilitation efforts. 
(2)  Rehabilitation is the responsibility of the employee. Any employee referred to the EAP is entitled to use accumulated sick leave, vacation or compensatory time, and the medical benefits entitled him under the medical insurance plan, subject to the prohibition described below. When accumulated leave is exhausted, the employee must request to be placed on a non-pay leave of absence. If the employee is placed on such leave for a period of 80 hours or more, (112 hours equivalent for fire department employees), or is otherwise placed on an approved leave of absence, he shall contact the mayor, or his designee, to investigate procedures for continuation of his medical plan. The city will not be responsible for payment of any charges in conjunction with rehabilitation except as provided by coverage under the city's medical insurance plan or other benefit plan. To be eligible for continuation of employment, regular reports must be submitted to the mayor or his designee, by the agency conducting the rehabilitation, and the employee must submit to testing, prior to returning to work and at unscheduled intervals thereafter for one year. This shall not constitute random testing as hereinbefore set forth and shall not be subject to any limitation as to the number of times said test may be required. A positive drug or alcohol screen during this time may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. Upon successful completion of treatment and testing, the employee may be returned to active status without reprisal. 
(3)  Any employee who initially rejects referral to the EAP or who leaves the EAP prior to being properly discharged therefrom will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. No employee will be eligible for a referral to the EAP more than one time. 
(4)  Any employee who has developed an addiction to, dependence upon, or problem with alcohol or drugs is encouraged to voluntarily contact the EAP for assistance. The EAP is confidential in nature. No reprisal will be taken against any employee who chooses to correct a drug or alcohol problem through voluntary participation in the EAP. However, such voluntary participation shall not be available if the employee is the subject of any type of drug and alcohol test hereunder, (i.e. notification of a test to be given). 
(k)  Record keeping. 
(1)  The city will keep or cause to be kept records of all test results in accordance with state and federal laws applicable to the preservation of records. At a minimum the following will be undertaken. 
a.  Records that demonstrate the collection process conform to all state/federal laws will be kept for three years. 
b.  Records of employee drug test results that show employees failed a drug or alcohol test; the type of test failed, and records that demonstrate rehabilitation, if any, will be kept for a period of five years. Refusals to take a drug and/or alcohol test shall also be kept five years. 
c.  Records of employee drug test results that show employees passed a drug test will be kept for one year. 
d.  A record of the number of employees that passed drug tests will be kept for five years. 
e.  Records confirming that supervisors and employees have been trained as required by this policy will be kept for three years. Training records will include copies of all training materials. 
1.  Medical and employment questionnaires or histories (including job description and occupational exposures), results of medical exams and lab tests (including chest and other x-ray exams taken for the purposes of establishing a baseline or detecting occupational illness, and all biological monitoring not defined as an "employee exposure record". Included are medical opinions, diagnoses, progress notes and recommendations, descriptions of treatments and prescriptions and employee medical complaints. Destroy 30 years after termination of employment. 
2.  All information from an employee's or applicant's drug and alcohol test is confidential and only those individuals with a need to know are to be informed of test results. Disclosure of test results to any other person, agency, or organization is prohibited unless written authorization is obtained from the employee or applicant. The results of a positive drug test shall not be released until the results are confirmed. The records of unconfirmed positive test results and negative test results shall be destroyed by the testing laboratory. 
(l)  Training. Supervisors shall receive an initial training class on this policy to include recognizing symptoms for reasonable suspicion testing. 
(Ord. No. 6-16, § 2, 3-14-16) 
Secs. 12-22-12-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CODE OF ETHICS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-94, §§ 1-31, adopted Nov. 13, 1995, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of its provisions as Art. III, Divs. 1-5 of this chapter has been at the discretion of the editor. For a detailed analysis of inclusion of the provisions of Ord. No. 14-94, see the Code Comparative Table near the end of this volume. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-51. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Mayfield Code of Ethics." 
(Ord. No. 14-94, § 1, 11-13-95) 
State Law reference- Mandate for a code of ethics for city officials and employees, KRS 65.003. 
Sec. 12-52. - Findings. 
    The legislative body of the City of Mayfield finds and declares that: 
(1)  Public office and employment with the city are public trusts. 
(2)  The vitality and stability of the government of this city depends upon the public's confidence in the integrity of its elected and appointed officers and employees. Whenever the public perceives a conflict between the private interest and public duties of a city officer or employee, that confidence is imperiled. 
(3)  The government of this city has a duty to provide its citizens with standards by which they may determine whether public duties are being faithfully performed, and to make its officers and employees aware of the standards which the citizenry rightfully expects them to comply with while conducting their public duties. 
(Ord. No. 14-94, § 2, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 12-53. - Purpose and authority. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this article to provide a method of assuring that standards of ethical conduct and financial disclosure requirements for officers and employees of the city shall be clearly established, uniform in their application, and enforceable, and to provide the officers and employees of the city with advice and information concerning potential conflicts of interest which might arise in the conduct of their public duties. 
(b)  It is the further purpose of this article to meet the requirements of KRS Ch. 65, as enacted by the 1994 Kentucky General Assembly. 
(c)  This article is enacted under the power vested in the city by KRS 82.082 and pursuant to requirements of KRS Ch. 65. 
(Ord. No. 14-94, § 3, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 12-54. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
    Business means any corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, firm, enterprise, franchise, association, organization, self-employed individual, holding company, joint stock company, receivership, trust, professional service corporation, or any legal entity through which business is conducted for profit. 
    Board of ethics means the City of Mayfield Board of Ethics which is created and vested by this article with the responsibility of enforcing the requirements of the city's code of ethics. 
    Candidate means any individual who seeks nomination or election to a city office. An individual is a candidate when the individual files a notification and declaration for nomination for office with the county clerk or secretary of state, or is nominated for office by a political party, or files a declaration of intent to be a write-in candidate with the county clerk or secretary of state. 
    City refers to the City of Mayfield, Kentucky. 
    City agency means any board, commission, authority, nonstock corporation, or other entity created, either individually or jointly, by this city. 
    Employee means any person, whether full-time or part-time, and whether paid or unpaid, who is employed by or provides service to the city. The term "employee" shall not include any contractor or subcontractor or any of their employees. 
    Family member means a spouse, parent, child, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law, grandparent or grandchild. 
    Immediate family member means a spouse, and unemancipated child residing in the officer's or employee's household, or a person claimed by the officer or employee, or the officer's or employee's spouse, as a dependent for tax purposes. 
    Officer means any person, whether full-time or part-time, and whether paid or unpaid, who is one of the following: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  A legislative body member; i.e., (a city council member). 
(3)  The city clerk. 
(4)  Planning and public works director. 
(5)  The fire chief. 
(6)  The police chief. 
(7)  Any person who occupies a nonelected office created under KRS 83A.080. 
(8)  A member of the governing body of any city agency who has been appointed to the governing body of the agency by the city, or any agency officer appointed by the governing body of any city agency. 
(Ord. No. 14-94, § 4, 11-13-95; Ord. No. 5-16, § 1, 3-14-16) 
Secs. 12-55-12-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STANDARDS OF CONDUCT 

Sec. 12-71. - Conflicts of interest in general. 
    Every officer and employee of the city and every city agency shall comply with the following standards of conduct: 
(1)  No officer or employee, or any immediate family member of any officer or employee, shall have an interest in a business or engage in any business, transaction, or activity, which is in substantial conflict with the proper discharge of the officer's or employee's public duties. 
(2)  No officer or employee shall intentionally use or attempt to use his or her official position with the city to secure unwarranted privileges or advantages for himself or herself or others. 
(3)  No officer or employee shall intentionally take or refrain from taking any discretionary action, or agree to take or refrain from taking any discretionary action, or induce or attempt to induce any other officer or employee to take or refrain from taking any discretionary action, on any matter before the city in order to obtain a financial benefit for any of the following: 
a.  The officer or employee. 
b.  A family member. 
c.  An outside employer. 
d.  Any business in which the officer or employee, or any family member has a financial interest. 
e.  Any business with which the officer or employee or any family member is negotiating or seeking prospective employment or other business or professional relationship. 
(4)  No officer or employee shall be deemed in violation of any provision in this section if, by reason of the officer's or employee's participation, vote, decision, action or inaction, no financial benefit accrues to the officer or employee, a family member, an outside employer, or a business as defined in subsection (3)d and (3)e of this section, as a member of any business, occupation, profession, or other group, to any greater extent than any gain could reasonably be expected to accrue to any other member of the business, occupation, profession, or other group. 
(5)  Every officer or employee who has a prohibited financial interest which the officer or employee believes or has reason to believe may be affected by his or her participation, vote decision or other action taken within the scope of his or her public duties shall disclose the precise nature and value of the interest to the governing body of the city or city agency served by the officer or employee, and the disclosure shall be entered on the official record of the proceedings of the governing body. The officer or employee shall refrain from taking any action with respect to the matter that is the subject of the disclosure. 
(Ord. No. 14-94, § 5, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 12-72. - Conflicts of interest in contracts. 
(a)  No officer or employee of the city or any city agency shall directly or through others undertake, execute, hold, or enjoy, in whole or in part, any contract made, entered into, awarded, or granted by the city or a city agency, except as follows: 
(1)  The prohibition in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to contracts entered into before an elected officer filed as a candidate for city office, before an appointed officer was appointed to a city or city agency office, or before an employee was hired by the city or a city agency. However, if any contract entered into by a city or city agency officer or employee before he or she became a candidate, was appointed to office, or was hired as an employee, is renewable after he or she becomes a candidate, assumes the appointed office, or is hired as an employee, then the prohibition in subsection (A) of this section shall apply to the renewal of the contract. 
(2)  The prohibition in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply if the contract is awarded after public notice and competitive bidding, unless the officer or employee is authorized to participate in establishing the contract specifications, awarding the contract, or managing contract performance after the contract is awarded. If the officer or employee has any of the authorities set forth in the preceding sentence, then the officer or employee shall have no interest in the contract, unless the requirements set forth in subpart (3) below are satisfied. 
(3)  The prohibition in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply in any case where the following requirements are satisfied: 
a.  The specific nature of the contract transaction and the nature of the officer's or employee's interest in the contract are publicly disclosed at a meeting of the governing body of the city or city agency. 
b.  The disclosure is made a part of the official record of the governing body of the city or city agency before the contract is executed.
