A franchisee shall not, as a condition of providing service, require a subscriber or potential subscriber to remove any existing antenna, or to disconnect an antenna except at the express direction of the subscriber or potential subscriber, provided that such antenna is connected with an appropriate device and complies with applicable law 
(Ord. No. 1-99, § 5, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 14-86. - Enforcement generally. 
    The franchisee shall not be relieved of its obligation to comply promptly with any of the provisions of the franchise by any failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance. 
(Ord. No. 1-99, § 6, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 14-87. - Security fund. 
(a)  Prior to a franchise or franchise renewal becoming effective, the franchisee shall post with the city a cash security deposit in an amount as determined by the city. The deposit is to be used as a security fund to ensure the faithful performance of all provisions of law and the franchise agreement and compliance with all orders, permits and directions of the city and the payment by the franchise of any fees, claims, liquidated damages, liens or taxes due the city which arise by reason of the construction, operation or maintenance of the system. 
(b)  The city shall place the security deposit in an interest bearing account. The interest will accrue to the benefit of the franchisee, but may not be withdrawn during the franchise term and any renewal thereof. All interest will be added to and become a part of the original security fund during the term of the franchise and any renewal thereof. 
(c)  Within 30 days after notice to it that any amount has been withdrawn from the security fund, the franchisee shall pay to or deposit with the city funds sufficient to restore such security fund. 
(d)  If the franchisee fails to pay the city any compensation within the time fixed herein or fails, after 30 days' notice, to pay the city any fees or taxes due or fails to pay or repay to the city within 30 days, any damages, costs or expenses which the city shall be compelled to pay by reason of any act or default of a franchisee in connection with the franchise agreement or fails, after 30 days' notice of such failure by the city, to comply with any provisions of the franchise agreement which the city reasonably determines can be remedied by an expenditure of the security, the city may immediately withdraw the amount due, with interest and any penalties, from the security fund. Upon such withdrawal, the city shall notify the franchisee of the amount and date thereof. Within 30 days of such withdrawal, the franchisee shall replenish the fund in the amount of the withdrawal. 
(e)  The security fund deposited pursuant to this section shall become the property of the city in the event the franchise agreement is canceled by reason of the default of the franchisee. The franchisee, however, shall be entitled to the return of such security fund, or portion thereof, as remains at the expiration of the term of the franchise agreement and any renewal thereof, provided that there is then no outstanding default on the part of the franchisee. Interest earned by the investment of the security fund will accrue to the franchisee. 
(f)  The rights reserved to the city with respect to the security fund are in addition to all other rights of the city whether reserved by this article or authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such security fund shall affect any other right the city may have. 
(g)  The franchise agreement may contain a schedule of liquidated damages, and the city may obtain reimbursement from the security fund for any unpaid liquidated damages that may exist. 
(Ord. No. 1-99, § 7, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 14-88. - Cable customer service standards for franchised cable television systems. 
(a)  Special requirements for the disabled. In addition to any other requirements mandated by this article, or by federal or city law, a franchisee shall comply with the following special service requirements for sight- or hearing-impaired, or wheelchair customers: 
(1)  Provide wheelchair accessibility to a franchisee's customer service office; 
(2)  For any customer declared legally blind by the state, a franchisee must provide, if requested by customer, large type, braille, voice synthesized or functionally equivalent notices, bills, and other pertinent information; 
(3)  Provide at a non-discriminatory cost, a special closed captioned converter for the hearing-impaired; 
(4)  Provide at a non-discriminatory cost, a remote control device and/or converter for wheelchair subscribers or subscribers with a permanent medical or physical ambulatory impairment; and 
(5)  Where applicable, provide modified or special instructions for use of equipment by subscribers who have physical impairments. 
(b)  Restoration of a subscriber's property. If at any time a franchisee disturbs the yard, residence, or other real or personal property, it shall be returned, replaced, and/or restored to a condition that is comparable to its condition before the disturbance. To the extent such corrective action cannot be accomplished, the franchisee shall reimburse a subscriber, or private property owner, for any damage caused by the franchisee, subcontractor, or independent contractor, in connection with the disturbance of a subscriber's or other person's property. 
(c)  Emergency alert; standby power. 
(1)  In order that subscribers may be alerted in the event of an impending, imminent or actual, natural, manmade, or disaster emergency, the franchisee shall insure that the cable television system providing cable television service to all, or part, of the city is designed so as to be in compliance with applicable federal requirements. Moreover, the franchisee shall, in the case of a disaster emergency, make the entire cable television system available without charge to the city or to any governmental or civil defense agency that the city shall designate. 
(2)  In addition to any other requirements listed in this article, a franchisee shall: 
a.  Cooperate with the city on the use and operation of the emergency alert override system; and 
b.  Develop a plan (with the city's concurrence) on methods to provide continuity of cable television service, and response to service calls in the event of a natural, manmade, or disaster emergency. 
c.  As one method of providing continuity of services in the event of a natural, manmade, or disaster emergency, a franchisee shall, unless exempted by the city, maintain equipment capable of providing automatic standby power for a minimum of two hours strategically placed in locations along the cable television system trunkline in order to minimize the number of subscribers affected by interruption of service. 
(d)  Telephone and office availability. 
(1)  Each franchisee shall maintain an office at a location, convenient to subscribers, and shall establish a telephone system adequate to respond to subscriber inquiries. Every franchisee must at least satisfy the minimum requirements established by the Federal Communications Commission. Each franchisee shall maintain an office and telephone system in accordance with a written plan submitted by the franchisee and approved by the Mayfield Cable Authority (MCA). Failure on the part of any franchisee to have and conform to an approved plan shall constitute a substantial violation of its franchise. A franchisee may propose new plans as often an practical, however, the MCA reserves the right to reject any proposal submitted. 
Each franchisee shall perform service calls, installations, and disconnects at least ten hours per day, Monday through Saturday (except legal holidays), provided that a franchisee shall respond to system outages 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 
(e)  Scheduling work. 
(1)  All appointments for service, installation, or disconnection shall be specified by date. Each franchisee shall specify a specific time at which the work shall be done, or offer a choice of time blocks, which shall not exceed two hours in length. A franchisee may also, upon request, schedule service installation calls outside normal business hours, for the express convenience of the customer. If at any time an installer or technician is running late for an appointment and believes it will not be able to make a scheduled appointment time, an attempt to contact the customer will be made prior to the time of appointment, and the appointment rescheduled at a time convenient to the customer, if rescheduling is necessary. It is the operator's burden to prove it met the appointment. 
(2)  The franchisee shall offer and fully describe to subscribers who have experienced a missed appointment (where the missed appointment was not the subscriber's fault) that the subscriber may choose between the following options: installation or service call free of charge or one month of the most widely subscribed to service tier free of charge. 
(3)  With regard to disabled or handicapped customers, upon subscriber request, each franchisee shall arrange for pickup and/or replacement of converters or other franchisee equipment at the subscriber's address or by a satisfactory equivalent (such as the provision of a postage-prepaid mailer). 
(4)  Under normal operating conditions, requests for service, repair, and maintenance must be acknowledged by a trained customer service representative within 24 hours, or prior to the end of the next business day, whichever is earlier. A franchisee shall respond to all other inquiries (including billing inquiries) within five business days of the inquiry or complaint. Under normal operating conditions, work on outages or service interruptions must begin immediately. Repairs and maintenance for outages or interruptions must be completed as soon as possible and within four hours after the outage or interruption becomes known to the franchisee where the franchisee has adequate access to facilities to which it must have access in order to remedy the problem. Under normal operating conditions, work to correct all other service problems must be begun by the next business day after notification of the service problem, and must be completed within five business days from the date of the initial request. When normal operating conditions do not exist, a franchisee shall complete the work in the shortest time possible. The failure of the franchisee to hire sufficient staff or to properly train its staff shall not justify the failure of the franchisee to comply with this provision. 
(5)  A franchisee shall not cancel a service or installation appointment with a customer after the close of business on the business day preceding the scheduled appointment. 
(6)  Under normal operating conditions, the standards of paragraphs 14-88(e)(1) and 14-88(e)(4) of this section shall be met at least 95 percent of the time, measured on a quarterly basis. 
Requests for additional outlets, service upgrades or other connections (e.g., DMX, VCR, A/B switch) separate from the initial installation will be performed within seven business days after an order has been placed. 
(f)  Notice to subscribers. 
(1)  At the time service is installed, a franchisee shall provide each subscriber with clear and accurate written information on the procedure for placing a service call, filing a complaint, or requesting an adjustment (including when a subscriber is entitled to refunds for outages and how to obtain them); showing the telephone number of the city office responsible for administering the franchise; the availability of parental control devices; the delinquent subscriber disconnect and reconnect policies and any other policies in connection with its subscribers. A franchisee shall also provide subscribers with a schedule of rates and charges, channel positions and services provided, as well as a copy of the service contract. The same information shall be provided to the subscriber annually thereafter, except another copy of the service contract need not be provided. Copies of the notices provided to the subscribers shall be provided to the city. Except as applicable federal, state and local rate regulations may provide to the contrary, a franchisee shall provide the Mayfield Cable Authority at least 60 days' notice and all subscribers at least 30 days' notice of any significant changes in the information required to be provided in this article. 
a.  Such notice shall be made in writing. 
(2)  Each franchisee shall take appropriate steps to ensure that all written franchisee promotional materials, announcements, and advertising of residential cable television to subscribers and the general public, where price information is listed in any manner, clearly and accurately discloses price terms. In the case of telephone orders, a franchisee shall take appropriate steps to ensure that price terms are clearly and accurately disclosed to potential customers in advance of taking the order. 
(3)  Each franchisee shall maintain a file open for public inspection containing all notices provided to subscribers under these customer service standards, as well as all promotional offers made to subscribers. The notices and offers shall be kept in the file for at least one year from the date of such notice or promotional offer. 
(g)  Interruptions of service. A franchisee shall provide 48 hours' prior notice to subscribers and the city before interrupting service for planned maintenance or construction; provided, however, that planned maintenance that does not require more than two hours interruption of service, and that occurs between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., shall not require such notice to subscribers, however, notice to the city must be given no less than 24 hours prior to the anticipated service interruption. 
(h)  Billing. 
(1)  A franchisee's first billing statement after a new installation or service charge shall be prorated as appropriate and shall reflect any security deposit. 
(2)  A franchisee's billing statement must be clear, concise and understandable, must itemize each category of service and equipment provided to the subscriber, and must state clearly the charge therefor. 
(3)  A franchisee's billing statement must show a specific payment due date not earlier than the later of: (1) 15 days after the date the statement is mailed; or (2) the 15th day of the 30-day period in which the service being billed is rendered. A late fee or administrative fee may not be imposed for payments before the end of the period for which the payment is rendered. Subscribers shall not be charged a late fee or otherwise penalized for any failure by a franchisee, including failure to timely or correctly bill the subscriber, or failure to property credit the subscriber for a payment timely made. 
(4)  A franchisee's bill must permit a subscriber to remit payment by mail or in person at the franchisee's local office. 
(5)  The account of any subscriber shall be credited a prorated share of the monthly charge for the service upon subscriber request, if a subscriber is without service or if service is substantially impaired for any reason for a period exceeding four hours during any 24-hour period; or automatically, if the loss of service or impairment is for 24 hours or longer, except where it can be documented that a subscriber will obtain a refund for a loss of service or impairment which was caused by the subscriber or by subscriber-owned equipment (not including, for purposes of this section, in-home wiring installed by the franchisee). 
(6)  A franchisee shall respond to all written billing complaints from subscribers within 30 days. 
(7)  Refunds to subscribers shall be issued no later than (A) the earlier of the subscriber's next billing cycle following resolution of the refund request, or 30 days; or (B) within 30 days of the date of return of all equipment to franchisee, if cable television service has been terminated. 
(8)  Credits for cable television service shall be issued no later than the subscriber's next billing cycle after the determination that the credit is warranted. 
(i)  Disconnection/downgrades. 
(1)  A subscriber may terminate service at any time. 
(2)  A franchisee shall promptly disconnect from the franchisee's cable television system or downgrade any subscriber who so requests. No period of notice prior to voluntary termination or downgrade of cable may be required of subscribers by any franchisee. Charges for any voluntary disconnection, and any downgrade charges shall conform to applicable law. 
(3)  Any security deposit and/or other funds due a subscriber that disconnects or downgrades service shall be returned to the subscriber within 30 days or in the next billing cycle, whichever is later, from the date the disconnection or the downgrade was requested, except in cases where the subscriber does not permit the franchisee to recover its equipment in which case the amounts owed shall be paid to subscribers within 30 days of the date the equipment was recovered, or in the next billing cycle, whichever is later. 
(4)  A franchisee may not disconnect a subscriber's cable television service for nonpayment unless: 
a.  The subscriber is delinquent in payment for cable television service; 
b.  A written notice of impending disconnection, postage prepaid, has been sent to the subscriber at least 20 days' prior to the date on which service may be disconnected, at the premises where the subscriber requests billing, which notice must state the date by which disconnection may occur, and the amount the subscriber must pay to avoid disconnection; 
c.  The subscriber has failed to pay the amounts owed to avoid disconnection by the date of disconnection; and 
d.  No pending inquiry exists regarding the bill to which franchisee has not responded in writing. Payment is not delinquent until the 15th day of the month in which the service being billed for is rendered; the notice required in this article may not be sent to a subscriber prior to the delinquency date. If the subscriber pays all amounts due, including late charges, before the date scheduled for disconnection, the franchisee shall not disconnect service. After lawful disconnection (except in cases where disconnection is also subject to the requirements in this article), upon payment by the subscriber in full of all proper fees or charges, including the payment of the reconnection charge, if any, the franchisee shall promptly reinstate service. 
(5)  A franchisee may immediately disconnect a subscriber if (A) the subscriber is damaging, destroying, or unlawfully tampering with or has damaged or destroyed or unlawfully tampered with the franchisee's cable television system; (B) the subscriber is not authorized to receive a service, and is facilitating, aiding or abetting the unauthorized receipt of service by others; or (C) subscriber-installed or attached equipment is resulting in signal leakage which is in violation of FCC rules. After disconnection, the franchisee shall restore service after the subscriber provides adequate assurance that it has ceased the practices that led to disconnection, and has paid all proper fees and charges, including any reconnect fees and all amounts owed to the franchisee for damage to its cable television system or equipment. However, a reconnect fee may not be levied where the subscriber was disconnected for signal leakage, unless the subscriber was notified of the leakage problem in writing, and the subscriber has failed to correct the leakage within three business days after receiving written notice of the problem from the franchise. 
(j)  Deposits. A franchisee may require a reasonable, non-discriminatory deposit on equipment provided to subscribers. Deposits shall be placed in an interest-bearing account, and the franchisee shall return the deposit plus interest earned to the date the deposit is returned to the subscriber, less any amount the franchisee can demonstrate should be deducted for damage to such equipment. 
(k)  Parental control option. Without limiting a franchisee's obligations under federal law, a franchisee must provide parental control devices for sale or lease at a reasonable charge to all subscribers who request them that enable the subscriber to block the video and audio portion of any channel or channels of programming. 
(l)  Voluntary disconnections. 
(1)  At any time, a subscriber may request that a particular service tier, service cluster, pay channel, premium channel, informational service, or the entire cable television service be discontinued. 
(2)  From the date that such a subscriber makes such a request, then the franchisee shall have 72 hours or three service days, whichever is longer, to disconnect the service tier, service cluster, pay channel, premium channel, informational service, or entire cable television service. In the event that a franchisee does not disconnect service within 72 hours, a subscriber's obligation to pay for such service shall cease. 
(3)  For a service tier, service cluster, premium channel, or informational service which is voluntarily disconnected, a subscriber shall pay a pro rata share of the monthly rate for such service or channel. 
(4)  Notwithstanding the above provisions, and in order to reduce subscriber abuse of this voluntary disconnection policy, a subscriber shall be charged a minimum of one month's full rate for any one service (basic, premium, informational, cluster, or tier) which is disconnected at least three times in a span of 180 days. 
(5)  Unless damage has occurred, no charge may be passed onto a subscriber for the actual disconnection of a channel or service, if the disconnection involves a single residence with fewer than five outlets. 
(6)  Any refund due a subscriber after disconnection (both for non-payment and voluntary) shall be made within 30 days after such disconnection. 
(m)  Substandard picture quality; remedies. 
(1)  A franchisee must meet all FCC technical standards that relate to picture and service quality and any such standards contained in the franchise agreement. 
(2)  If the franchisee does not correct a substandard picture or audio quality following an initial service call to the subscriber's residence, then subsequent service calls to correct the problem shall be at no charge. 
(3)  A customer shall be responsible for any damage caused to equipment rented or leased from a franchisee. 
(n)  Continuity of service. The city declares that as part of its right to establish cable television customer service guidelines, it has the duty to ensure continuity of cable television service for all subscribers. The city may take appropriate measures in order to insure that no portion of the city is threatened or faced with a disruption, interruption, or discontinuance of cable television service due to the actions of the franchisee. Whenever any situation occurs which threatens the continuity of cable television service, then the city may direct the franchisee to take certain action, reasonably within its power, to insure that all subscribers receive continuous, uninterrupted cable television service. 
(o)  Resolution of complaints/inquiries. 
(1)  A franchisee is required to develop a comprehensive complaint/inquiry resolution policy that is consistent with the policies outlined in these customer service practices. Before implementing the complaint/inquiry resolution policy, the city shall review the policy together with any amendments that might be added from time to time. 
(2)  A franchisee's resolution policy shall be reduced to writing, and such policy shall be available upon request to any person. 
(p)  Fair employment and contracting practices. A franchisee shall comply with all federal, state and local laws and regulations pertaining to fair employment and contracting practices. 
(q)  Construction. This article shall be construed in light of applicable Commonwealth of Kentucky and federal laws and regulations governing open video systems and cable practices in general, and open video systems and cable television consumer practices in particular. 
(r)  Effect on new and existing franchisees and licensees. 
(1)  For persons awarded a cable television or open video franchise or license after the effective date of this article, this article shall have full effect, and be enforceable in its entirety. 
(2)  For a franchisee or licensee existing on the date that this article becomes effective, then the article shall have no effect during the present franchise term to the extent it would modify contractual obligations under a pre-existing franchise or license agreement. However, concurrent with the franchisee's or licensee's executing a renewed franchise agreement, then the article shall have full effect, and be enforceable in its entirety. 
(s)  Delegation of power. Consistent with Kentucky law, the council may delegate its powers and responsibilities (except its ultimate franchising authority) hereunder with respect to cable television or open video systems to the Mayfield Cable Authority, or other duly authorized representative of the city, including the mayor, or city clerk. All filings with the city to be made by a franchisee under this article or a franchise agreement shall be made with the city clerk unless the franchisee is advised otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1-99, § 8, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 14-89. - Relation to other standards. 
    Nothing in these standards shall be read to relieve a cable television operator of an obligation to comply with federal, state or local consumer protection laws, to relieve an operator of an obligation to comply with stricter cable television customer service standards, or to foreclose remedies that may be available to subscribers under applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 1-99, § 9, 7-10-00) 
Sec. 14-90. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Captions. The captions to sections throughout this article are intended solely to facilitate reading and reference to the sections and provisions of this article. Such captions shall not affect the meaning or interpretation of this article. 
(b)  Calculation of time. Unless otherwise indicated, when the performance or doing of any act, duty, matter, or payment is required under this article or any franchise or license and a period of time or duration for the fulfillment of doing thereof is prescribed and is fixed herein, the time shall be computed so as to exclude the first and include the last day of the prescribed or fixed period of duration time. 
(c)  Severability. If any term, condition, or provision of this article shall to any extent, be held to be invalid or unenforceable by a valid order of any court or regulatory agency, the remainder hereof shall be valid in all other respects and continue to be effective. In the event of a subsequent change in applicable law, so that the provision which had been held invalid is no longer invalid, said provision shall thereupon return to full force and effect without any further action by the city and shall thereafter be binding on the franchisee by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1-99, § 10, 7-10-00) 
Chapter 15 - TAXATION OF PROPERTY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Occupational license taxes and earnings tax, Ch. 9; imposition of transient room tax, § 13-11; motor vehicle licenses, § 16-50 et seq. 
State Law reference- Finance and revenue of cities, KRS chs. 91A, 92; general power of cities to tax, KRS 92.280. 

Sec. 15-1. - County assessment adopted as basis. 
    Pursuant to authority granted by KRS ch. 132 the city shall for the purposes of levy and assessment of property taxes adopt and use the annual county assessment for property situated within the city as a basis for ad valorem tax levies. The assessment as finally determined for county tax purposes shall serve the city as a basis of all city levies for the fiscal year commencing after the county assessment date. 
(Ord. of 8-27-73, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 15-2. - Assessment dates; fiscal year; delinquency dates. 
(a)  The assessment dates for the city shall conform to the corresponding dates for the county, and the city taxes shall be levied after the county equalizers have equalized the assessment. 
(b)  The fiscal year is established as being from the first day of January to the first day of January. 
(c)  Delinquency dates for taxes are hereby fixed as January first of each year, following the tax year for which said tax is levied. 
(Ord. of 8-27-73, § 3) 
Sec. 15-3. - When payable. 
    The city taxes (and school taxes, if the Mayfield Independent Board of Education selects the city clerk-tax collector as its collector) shall be payable at the same time as state and county ad valorem taxes are due and payable. 
(Ord. No. 1-83, § 3, 1-24-83) 
Sec. 15-4. - Billing; place of payment; delinquency interest; advertising cost. 
(a)  These taxes shall be billed in the same manner as state and county ad valorem taxes, using the tax roll and assessment provided through the office of the property valuation administrator, as adopted by ordinance. The place for payment for these taxes shall be at the office of the city clerk-tax collector, in the city hall. 
(b)  Taxes for each year not paid on or before December thirty-first of that tax year, bear a penalty of ten percent of the total tax unpaid at January first, plus interest at the rate of eight percent per annum until paid. Additionally, delinquent taxpayers will be assessed $5.00 per tax bill advertised in the newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 1-83, § 3(1), 1-24-83) 
State Law reference- See KRS 132.010 et seq. 
Sec. 15-5. - Levy on personal property; garnishment. 
    The city clerk-tax collector shall have power to levy upon personal property to satisfy the amount due by each taxpayer, and shall have the same powers given by law to the sheriff for the collection of taxes by garnishment. 
(Ord. No. 1-83, § 3(2), 1-24-83) 
Sec. 15-6. - Advertising for sale delinquent taxes. 
    The city clerk-tax collector shall advertise for sale all delinquent taxes of each taxpayer not paid, in accordance with the powers vested by the Kentucky Revised Statutes, and enough of the taxpayers' property shall be levied upon to satisfy the taxes remaining unpaid, and the clerk shall execute deeds to all persons who purchase said property according to law. 
(Ord. No. 1-83, § 3(3), 1-24-83) 
State Law reference- See KRS 92.570 et seq.; motor vehicle ad valorem taxation, KRS 132.487. 
Sec. 15-7. - Filing list of delinquents. 
    The city clerk-tax collector is hereby directed to make a list of all delinquent taxes and file them in the county clerk's office as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1-83, § 3(5), 1-24-83) 
Sec. 15-8. - Use of proceeds. 
    All funds from the tax levy shall be paid into the general fund of the city, and be used for general governmental expenditures, in accordance with the budget theretofore filed in the city clerk's office, except that the $0.03 levied on the $100.00 valuation of all property subject to city taxation for the policemen's and firemen's pension fund shall be paid into said fund. 
(Ord. No. 1-83, § 3(4), 1-24-83) 
Sec. 15-9. - Exemption for manufacturing establishments. 
(a)  Statutory authority. KRS 92.300(1) grants the authority to cities of the third class to exempt manufacturing establishments from city taxation for a period not exceeding five years as an inducement to their location. Two-thirds of the members of the city legislative body must concur for this purpose. 
(b)  Exemption declared. The city council deems it desirable to offer this exemption to all manufacturing establishments as an inducement to locate their business within the city. 
(c)  Applicability. The exemption applies to all real and personal property tax and is for a period not exceeding five years. The exemption does not apply to city school tax nor to state or county taxes. 
(d)  Application for exemption; renewals. The request for the exemption should be filed with the city clerk in form and content acceptable to the clerk. The original application must be filed at least 30 days prior to moving into the city; however, this provision may be waived by the council under extraordinary circumstances. Renewal applications are to be submitted to the city clerk in the same format as the original application prior to September first each year for the duration of the exempt period. Each renewal must be voted on with two-thirds of the members of the legislative body concurring. 
(Ord. No. 13-87, §§ 1-4, 12-29-87) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-87, adopted Dec. 29, 1987, was nonamendatory of the Code; hence codification of §§ 1-4 as § 15-9 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 15-10. - Reserved.

Chapter 16 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Driving or parking vehicles in cemeteries, § 5-8; creation of noise, § 7-4(1), (4), (5); spilling of load by vehicle, § 7-25; hours of transportation of garbage, § 7-26. 
State Law reference- Uniform traffic citation, KRS 431.450; licensing of motor vehicles, operators and trailers, KRS ch. 186; financial responsibility law, KRS ch. 187; traffic regulations and vehicle equipment and storage, KRS ch. 189; driving under the influence, KRS ch. 189A; motor vehicle sales, KRS ch. 190. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Sight obstructions. 
(a)  In order to prevent hazardous driving conditions in the city and to preserve the health and welfare of its citizens and to protect their property, the maintenance of signs or obstructions on street right-of-way or on private property or permitting the branches of trees and shrubs on street right-of-way or on private property, where same interfere with vision of operators of motor vehicles on the streets of said city is prohibited. 
(b)  Where these hazardous conditions exist, the property owner will first be notified to eliminate these conditions and upon the property owner's failure to comply, the city shall remove the obstructions to the extent necessary to provide vision clearance and the costs of such removal shall be charged to the property owner and added to the property owner's tax bill. 
(Ord. of 9-22-69, §§ 2, 3) 
Sec. 16-2. - Soliciting money in roadway. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether acting individually or in a group, and whether acting for such person's self, or for any organization, association or corporation, to block any road or street in the city, or to do any act designed to stop, slow or impede the movement of vehicular traffic for the purpose of soliciting money, or to solicit money from occupants of vehicles in a line of traffic. 
(Ord. of 9-8-69, § 1) 
Sec. 16-3. - Placing handbills in or on motor vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any handbills or circulars on or in any motor vehicle in the city. 
(Ord. of 9-24-62, § 2) 
Sec. 16-4. - Driving through filling station or parking lot. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle or bicycle through the driveway of a filling station or the parking area of a business, except for business purposes. 
(Ord. of 9-24-62, § 2) 
Sec. 16-5. - Spillage from vehicles-Precautions. 
    All persons hauling gravel, concrete, paper, debris and dirt, trash or other materials on the streets of the city shall haul same in a closed or covered bed, or in such a manner, that the same will not fall upon the streets. 
(Ord. of 3-14-27) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, KRS 189.150. 
Sec. 16-6. - Same-Inspection and enforcement. 
    All trucks carrying gravel, concrete, paper, debris and other materials in the city may be stopped and inspected by the police to see if said trucks are properly loaded so that the contents which the truck is carrying will not spill or fall upon the streets, and if any truck is not so loaded to prevent the spilling or falling of materials on the city streets. 
(Ord. of 9-25-61, § 2) 
Sec. 16-7. - Removing barricades; damaging warning lights. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove or take down any barricade lawfully placed across any street in the city, or to remove or destroy any lights placed thereon as signals. 
(Ord. of 1-11-26) 
Sec. 16-8. - Skating on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate upon the sidewalks of the city with roller skates or any other device. 
(Ord. of 7-10-22, § 1) 
Sec. 16-9. - Speed limits. 
(a)  Unless otherwise designated and posted, the speed limit on all city streets within the City Limits of the City of Mayfield, Kentucky shall be set at 25 miles per hour. 
(b)  The speed limit on Central Road where same borders or is adjacent to the J. U. Kevil Center and Davis Housing Project shall be 15 miles per hour. 
(c)  The speed limit on South Ninth Street beginning at the intersection of South Ninth Street and Farthing Street and extending north to the intersection of South Ninth Street and West Water Street shall be 35 miles per hour. 
(Ord. of 11-10-80, § 2; Ord. No. 4-83, § 2, 2-28-83; Ord. No 4-03, 4-14-03) 
State Law reference- Speed, KRS 189.390. 
Sec. 16-9.5. - Heavy truck traffic prohibited. 
    South Seventh Street from Walnut to College Street and East College Street from South Sixth Street to South Ninth Street are hereby closed to heavy truck traffic at all times. This is due to the extreme wear on these residential streets and the bridge on South Seventh Street which is not built to withstand the load imposed by heavy trucks. 
(Ord. No. 9-86, § 1, 6-24-86) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of nonamendatory Ord. No. 9-86, adopted as an emergency measure on June 24, 1986, has been codified as § 16-9.5 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 16-10. - Semi-trailer trucks prohibited-Portion of South Tenth Street. 
    The section of South Tenth Street between West Water Street and West Walnut Street is hereby closed to semi-trailer trucks at all times, day and night, as this street is not built to permit this type traffic. 
(Ord. No. 10-84, § 1, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 16-11. - Same-Portion of North First Street and East North Street. 
    The portion of North First Street between East Broadway and East North Street and East North Street between North First Street and North Fifth Street are hereby closed to semitrailer trucks at all times, day and night, as these streets are not built to permit this type traffic. 
(Ord. No. 19-84, § 1, 9-10-84) 
Sec. 16-11.1. - Restrictions on heavy commercial trucks and tractor trailer vehicles. 
    All through traffic by heavy commercial trucks (above 26,000 pounds), and all tractor trailer vehicles, shall be restricted to indicated state truck routes, along with addition of the following designated streets; 
    The 100 block of East Walnut Street 
    The 100 block of East Water Street 
    The 100 block of West Water Street 
    The 200 block of East Water Street 
(Ord. No. 14-91, § II, 1-13-92; Ord. No. 6-92, § II, 4-13-92) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-91, § II, adopted Jan. 13, 1992, as amended by Ord. No. 6-92, § II, adopted April 13, 1992, has been included herein at the discretion of the editor as § 16-11.1. 
Sec. 16-12. - Passageway for youth trainees on North Twelfth Street. 
    There shall be a walkway for the youth being trained in the Northside Church building, beginning on the west side of North Twelfth Street, and extending east to the east side of North Twelfth Street, between Lochridge Street on the south and Maple Avenue on the north and pedestrians using this right-of-way shall have the right-of-way over the vehicular traffic, and by reason thereof, all vehicular traffic going in a northerly or southerly direction, approaching this passageway shall come to a complete stop when same is being used by pedestrians, and shall not proceed across same until people using said passageway have completed their journey across said street. 
(Ord. of 11-10-80) 
Sec. 16-13. - Student passageway on South Tenth Street. 
    The four feet on the west side of the pavement on South Tenth Street beginning at College Street and extending south to city limits shall henceforth be limited exclusively as a passageway for students between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. to 3:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of each week during the school term. 
(Ord. of 9-25-61, § 2) 
Sec. 16-14. - One-way streets and alleys. 
(a)  Park Drive, the street running back of the football stadium, shall be a one-way street, between North Fifteenth and North Seventeenth Street, running west, with parking on the north side only, from 4:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. (Ord. of 5-12-80, § 2) 
(b)  Water Street from its intersection with south Seventh Street to South Twelfth Street shall be a one-way street, going west. (Ord. of 7-23-37, § 1; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(c)  South Twelfth Street from Water to Walnut Street shall be a one-way street, going south. 
(d)  Walnut Street from South Twelfth to South Seventh Street shall be a one-way street, going east. (Ord. of 7-23-37, § 1; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(e)  The alley running in an east-west direction between East South Street and East Water Street and from South Sixth Street to South Seventh Street, shall be a one-way alley running east and west, and all operators of vehicular traffic using this alley shall travel in a westerly direction. (Ord. of 3-10-80, § 2; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(f)  North Second Street beginning at East North Street and continuing to East Broadway shall be a one-way street, going south for all traffic. (Ord. of 9-24-62, § 2) 
(g)  The branch of North Seventh Street running in front of Watson's Grocery shall be a one-way street, beginning with the north line of Lee Street and extending in a northerly direction for a distance of 100 feet. (Ord. of 3-10-80, § 2) 
(h)  South Seventh Street between College Street and Cleveland Street shall be a one-way street going south, and only traffic going in a southerly direction may enter said street and proceed thereon. (Ord. of 10-22-51, § 2; Ord. of 9-13-76, § 2; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(i)  South Eighth Street between College Street and Cleveland Street shall be a one-way street going north, and only traffic going in a northerly direction may enter said street and proceed thereon. (Ord. of 10-22-51, § 2; Ord. of 9-13-76, § 2; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(j)  Reserved. (Ord. of 4-13-53, § 3; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(k)  South Tenth Street between West South Street and West Walnut Street shall be a one-way street going south and only traffic going in a southerly direction may enter said street and proceed thereon. (Ord. of 10-8-51, § 2; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(l)  South Eleventh Street between West Water Street and West Walnut Street shall be a one-way street going south. (Ord. of 8-10-53, § 2; Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
(m)  South Thirteenth Street between West Water and West South Street shall be a one-way street going north. (Ord. No. 1-88, § 1, 3-14-88) 
Sec. 16-15. - Railroad signalling device at Broadway crossing. 
    The Illinois Central Railroad Company or any other person operating a railroad company across Broadway Street shall erect and maintain in operation, the latest improved signalling and warning devices consisting of two standards, to be located one on each side of the Broadway crossing (each standard to have two flashing lights) and to be erected on the right side of traffic approaching the Broadway crossing; which signalling device is to operate alternating in such manner as to call attention of the traveling to the approach of trains, the reflection from same to be of red. If at any time the signalling device herein approved becomes temporarily inoperative due to accident or other unforseen cause, the railroad may substitute flagman protection, which flagman protection shall continue until the signalling device is again made operative. 
(Ord. of 9-19-32, § 1; Ord. of 10-24-32, § 1) 
Sec. 16-16. - No-left-turn intersections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person traveling in any vehicle, motor or otherwise to make a turn to the left going east at the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Street. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person traveling in any vehicle, motor or otherwise, to make a turn to the left going west at the intersection of Broadway and Seventh Street. (Ord. of 9-24-23, § 2) 
Sec. 16-17. - State highways designated as through streets. 
    All designated and marked state highways throughout the city are hereby designated as through streets or boulevards, except as otherwise provided herein, and traffic upon said highways shall have the right-of-way over traffic upon any other street. Said marked highways so designated being as follows: Broadway from the east to the west city limits; Seventh Street from the north city limits to Walnut Street, thence west to South Twelfth Street; Eighth Street from the north city limits to Water Street, thence west to South Twelfth Street; South Sixth Street from East Broadway to the south city limits. However, where an electric traffic signal appears upon any of such streets, the traffic signal shall control the right-of-way at such place. 
(Ord. of 4-21-47, § 1) 
Sec. 16-18. - North and south streets designated as through streets. 
    All streets in the city going north and south are hereby designated as through streets or boulevards, except as otherwise provided herein, and traffic thereon shall have the right-of-way over traffic going east or west, except traffic on Broadway and on West Water Street and West Walnut Street shall have the right-of-way over traffic going north and south mentioned herein. 
(Ord. of 4-21-47, § 1) 
Sec. 16-19. - Indiana Avenue designated as a through street. 
    Indiana Avenue shall be a through street or boulevard. 
(Ord. No. 2-84, § 1, 1-23-84)

Sec. 16-21. - Traffic regulations in work zones. 
(a)  The director of public works may, by official order, regulate the speed of motor vehicles in city street work zones by erecting a temporary speed limit sign during the periods that workers are in the area. 
(b)  As used in the section, "city street work zone", means that lane or portion of a city maintained street open to vehicular traffic and the effected area adjacent to a lane, berm or shoulder of a city maintained street upon which construction, reconstruction, resurfacing or other work of that nature is being conducted. 
(c)  Any temporary speed limit sign or warning device shall be placed in obvious positions on each end of the city street work zone. 
(d)  Operators of motor vehicles driving in excess of the temporary posted speed limit shall be subject to double the normal fine for the speeding violation. 
(e)  Operators of motor vehicles are further prohibited from entering closed and properly marked city street work zones, without authorization or direction from public works employees. Any operator of a motor vehicle who violates this subsection shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00 plus any court costs and damages to city property. 
(f)  Any city work zone referred to in this section shall be clearly marked and closed off by the placement of highway barricades, cones, drums, sign trucks, sign boards or other devices approved by the director of public works; and any temporary speed limit sign shall be clearly posted on each end of the city street work zone. 
(Ord. No. 25-98, 10-12-98) 
Secs. 16-22-16-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parking on Park Drive, § 16-14. 

Sec. 16-30. - Obstructing driveways and alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of a motor vehicle to park it in such a way and manner as to prevent the use of private driveways or public alleys in the city. 
(Ord. of 12-11-50, § 1) 
Sec. 16-31. - Parking near fire hydrant. 
    The parking of any vehicle within ten feet of any fire hydrant within the city is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 5-12-47, § 1) 
Sec. 16-32. - Fire lanes, etc., on private property. 
(a)  All private parking lots providing parking for more than ten vehicles are required to provide proper ways of ingress and egress through said parking lots, and to provide fire lane open spaces in order that fire equipment may have access to the buildings located on said lots, and the fire lanes, open spaces, or ways of ingress and egress should remain open at all times. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator of a motor vehicle to park in such fire lanes, open spaces, or ways of ingress and egress in such lots. 
(Ord. of 10-13-75, § 11) 
Sec. 16-33. - Handicapped parking areas. 
    The following areas are designated exclusively as parking areas for operators of motor vehicles carrying the handicapped persons as passengers: 
(1)  A space 25 feet in length and seven feet, nine inches in width located on the south side of Broadway at a point ten feet, one inch east from the curb at the intersection of South Sixth Street and Broadway. 
(2)  A space eight feet, seven inches in width and 18 feet in length on the east side of South Sixth Street, 30 feet north from the curb at the intersection of South Sixth Street and East South Street. 
(3)  A space eight feet, seven inches in width and 18 feet, four inches in length on the south side of South Street located 35 feet east from the curb of the intersection of South Seventh Street and West South Street. 
(4)  A space eight feet, four inches in width and 20 feet, two inches in length located on the west side of South Seventh Street, 34 feet, five inches from the curb at the intersection of South Seventh Street and West Broadway. 
(5)  Three handicapped parking spaces and an unloading zone shall be established on the south side of the First Methodist Church of Mayfield, Kentucky, on the north side of West Water Street, between Seventh and Eighth Streets. 
(6)  A handicap parking space shall be established on the east side of Seventh Street between Broadway and South Street which shall begin nine feet north of the north right-of-way line of South Street and shall extend 16 feet north in width along the east right-of-way line of Seventh Street and 18 feet west in length. 
(Ord. No. 2-83, § 2, 1-24-83; Ord. No. 2-92, § II, 2-10-92; Ord. No. 6-12, § 1, 4-9-12) 
Sec. 16-33.1. - Parking spaces reserved for handicapped persons. 
(a)  Unauthorized use prohibited. No person shall park, load, unload or stand any vehicle in any parking space designated for handicapped persons on public or private property unless that person is handicapped or unless the handicapped person is a passenger in the vehicle and unless the vehicle has a State of Kentucky card or sticker with a handicap logo displayed. The city is authorized to honor handicap cards or stickers issued by other agencies which have the same or similar qualifications. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended. 
(1)  Handicapped parking space, designated handicap space, and any variation thereof: A parking space designated for parking of a vehicle operated by a handicapped person or a vehicle in which a handicapped person is a passenger. 
(2)  Handicapped person: Any person to whom a card or sticker with a handicap logo has been issued in accordance with applicable state law. 
(c)  Obstruction of handicapped parking spaces. At no time shall designated handicapped spaces on public or private property be used for the storage of snow, trash, shopping carts, construction materials, or otherwise obstructed except when provisions have been made for additional, equally accessible, temporary handicapped parking spaces at least equal in number to the obstructed spaces. 
(d)  Parking prohibited in spaces designated for disabled persons. It is unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any vehicle in a stall or space designated for physically handicapped persons if, immediately adjacent to and visible from such stall or space, there is posted a sign known as the international wheelchair symbol consisting of a profile view of a stylized wheelchair with occupant in white on a blue background and, unless the driver of the car or person being transported is handicapped. 
(e)  Requirements of handicapped parking. 
(1)  All designated handicapped parking spaces shall be marked with a sign mounted on a substantial post or standard permanently fixed to or imbedded into the parking surface or on wall directly in front of the space, with the international symbol of accessibility, and the words "Handicapped Parking Only" or "Reserved Parking Only." The sign must be mounted high enough so it can be seen while a vehicle is parked in the space. The bottom of the sign must be a minimum of 60 [inches] above grade. 
(2)  All designated handicapped parking spaces shall be a minimum of eight feet by 18 feet in size except those in parallel parking areas of the city streets, the size of which shall not be less than eight feet by 24 feet in size. 
(3)  All designated handicapped parking spaces shall be those spaces located nearest one of the accessible routes to the building served by the parking area. 
(4)  In the event that any designated handicapped space is regularly and lawfully occupied by an employee in a parking area used by the public, an additional designated handicapped space shall be provided for each occupied space. 
(5)  Handicap placards and/or plates must be properly installed on a rear view mirror or license plate. Those who fail to properly display handicap placard or plates will be subject to a fine of $10.00. 
(6)  Persons who improperly or illegally use handicap placards or plates and who have not been certified as handicapped and are not entitled by law to use such placards or plates will be subject to a fine of $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 11-92, §§ II, III, 4-13-92; Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 16-04, § 2, 11-8-04) 
Sec. 16-34. - No parking areas; loading and unloading areas. 
(a)  At any time it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a policeman or traffic control device: 
(1)  Within 20 feet of any intersection, unless otherwise designated as a parking or no parking area. 
(2)  In a crosswalk. 
(3)  Upon any bridge or viaduct. 
(4)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On any sidewalk or parkway. 
(6)  At any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight carrying vehicles for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed 30 minutes, or in any place designated by ordinance as a loading zone and marked as such. 
(c)  On the following streets there shall be no parking; or parking for loading or unloading only; as indicated: 
South Second Street , south side, beginning at the intersection of Water Street and South Second Street and extending west to the intersection of Water Street and South Third Street, no parking. 
South Second Street , west side, beginning at the intersection of South Second Street and Backusburg Road, and extending north to the intersection of South Second Street and East Broadway, no parking. 
South Third Street, beginning at the intersection of Douthitt Street and South Third Street running south to Paris Road, no parking. 
South Third Street , beginning at the intersection of Douthitt Street and South Third Street and running north 150 feet on the east and west sides of the street. 
North Fifth Street , beginning at the north border of the driveway of 222 North Fifth Street and running north 30 feet, and beginning at the south border of the driveway directly north of 228 North Fifth Street and running south 30 feet, no parking. 
South Fifth Street from East Water Street to Backusburg Road, no parking, except that parking is permitted on the east side of South Fifth Street beginning with East Water Street and extending south to East Walnut Street. 
South Fifth Street , east side, between Water Street and Walnut Street, no parking. 
South Fifth Street , west side, beginning at the intersection of East Broadway and South Fifth Street and continuing south on South Fifth Street to the intersection of South Fifth Street and East South Street, no parking. 
North Sixth Street , east side, between East Broadway and East North Street, no parking. 
South Sixth Street , beginning at the intersection of South Sixth Street and Water Street and extending south to the intersection of South Sixth Street and College Street, no parking. 
South Sixth Street , east side, beginning at the intersection of South Sixth Street and Walnut Street and running in a southerly direction to Backusburg Road, no parking. 
South Seventh Street , west side, between Broadway and South Street, there is created a loading/unloading zone for an area 22 feet wide and 16 feet long beginning 106 feet north of the north right-of-way line of South Street, to unload, load and deliver materials for a period not to exceed 30 minutes. 
South Eighth Street, west side, beginning at the intersection with North Street and extending north for 150 feet, no parking.

South Twelfth Street , between Water Street and Beech Street, no parking. 
North Thirteenth Street, both sides, between Depot and Lochridge Streets, no parking. 
South Fourteenth Street, east side, beginning at the intersection of South Fourteenth Street and Water Street and extending south to the intersection of South Fourteenth Street and Walnut Street, no parking.

East North Street, north side, extending west from North Sixth Street for a distance of three parking spaces, no parking. 
West North Street , south beginning at its intersection with North Eighth Street and extending westerly for 50 feet, no parking. 
Oak Street, south side in front of Apartment 510 of the Garden apartments beginning at the driveway at the west side of the building and extending east along Oak Street to the end of the building. 
South Street, northwest corner of the intersection of South Fifth Street and South Street, thence west 50 feet, no parking except for loading and unloading. 
South Street, at South Sixth Street, beginning at the intersection and thence west 50 feet, no parking except for loading and unloading.

Central Avenue, either side, from Cuba Road (KY 303) to South 10 th Street, unless that vehicle is expressly being used for emergency purposes. 
(d)  In the event of inclement weather resulting in snow, ice, or both, it shall be illegal to park vehicles on the street in any neighborhood or commercial areas, so that snow and ice removal vehicles can properly and safely remove snow and ice from street surfaces. 
(e)  Parking in any areas other than those designed for parking is prohibited at the Mayfield-Graves County Ballpark.

Sec. 16-35. - Two-hour parking zones; four hour parking zones; unlimited parking zones between 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m.; and court related parking. 
    Two-hour parking, four-hour parking, unlimited parking and court related parking between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. is permitted on the following named streets any day, unless there is more restrictive parking limits designated or during city sanctioned special events: 
(1)  Broadway, two-hour parking between Seventh Street and Eighth Street on both the north and south sides of Broadway. 
(2)  South Street north side from Fifth Street to Sixth Street two-hour parking West South Street, between North 7 th and North 8 th Streets, north side, two-hour parking extending to a point 197 feet from the intersection of South Seventh Street and South Street excluding a 40-foot posted unloading zone. 
(3)  North Seventh Street, two-hour parking between East North and Broadway on both the east and west sides of the street; two-hour parking on west side only between Broadway and South Street. 
(4)  That except for the various specifically designated zones in subsections (1)-(4) and as may be specifically designated in section 16-34, all other downtown parking from Fifth Street to Eighth Street and from North Street to Water Street shall be unlimited parking between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. unless there are more restrictive parking limits designated or during city sanctioned special events. 
(Ord. No. 3-11, § 2, 5-9-2011; Ord. No. 12-11, § 2, 8-8-11; Ord. No. 9-12, § 1, 1-14-13; Ord. No. 17-16, § 1, 6-13-16)

    Parking on South Eighth Street, beginning at the intersection of South Eighth Street and Water Street and extending south to the intersection of South Eighth Street and Walnut Street is limited to one hour. 
(Ord. of 3-14-66, § 2)

    A designated parking space shall be allowed for the state A.O.C. maintenance worker for the Graves County Courthouse. Said parking space to be located on the east side of South Seventh Street on the west side of the Graves County Courthouse.

Sec. 16-40. - Parking for law enforcement personnel. 
    Two additional "Law Enforcement Vehicle Only" parking spaces are to be added on the east side of the courthouse on South 6th Street. These will be between the existing "Jail Unloading" and handicapped parking areas. 
    The parking space designated for "Law Enforcement Vehicle Only" on the south side of the Courthouse on South Street, west of the sally port entrance, is hereby declared to be for jail staff parking only. 
(Ord. No. 7-03, §§ 1, 2, 4-14-03) 
Sec. 16-41. - Parking at curb. 
    No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to the curb, except on one-way streets, and it shall be unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel with the curb and with the two right wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the regularly established curb line, except that upon these streets that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-42. - Parking in right-of-way. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in the public right-of-way, regardless of operational status, for a period longer than 48 consecutive hours. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-43. - Cabstands and bus stands. 
    No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cabstand; and no vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-44. - Time limit parking. 
    Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a longer consecutive period of time than that designated between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. in any area designated as a limited parking area and so marked. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-45. - Parking motor vehicles on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property without the consent of the owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-46. - Signs. 
    The chief of police or any other person authorized by the mayor shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where parking is limited or prohibited by ordinance, indicating such limitations or prohibitions. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-47. - Alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-48. - Parking of recreational vehicles, commercial buses and vehicles over 10,000 pounds. 
    It is unlawful to park a recreational vehicle, commercial bus or vehicle over 10,000 pounds within 50 feet of the back of a curb or an edge of pavement. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 3-16, § 1, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 16-49. - All night parking of semitractors, semitrailers, trucks exceeding five tons, and school buses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any semitractor, semitrailer, truck exceeding five tons, or any school bus on the streets of any R-1, R-2 or R-3 residential district from 10:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-49.1. - Vehicles for sale. 
    It shall by unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03) 
Sec. 16-49.2. - School zones. 
    The no parking area on South Seventh between the alley running east-west and the point where Cleveland Street intersects South Seventh is hereby changed to be an area in which there is no parking during school hours or school-sponsored events, generally considered to be between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday during the times in which school is in session and at times when school events, contests, concerts and other extracurricular activities are occurring at Mayfield Middle School. 
(Ord. No. 4-04, § 1, 4-12-04) 
Sec. 16-49.3. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article, except for the handicapped parking provisions, and the Mayfield-Graves County Ballpark provisions, shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $50.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of section 16-33.1, handicapped parking, shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of section 16-34(e), prohibited parking at Mayfield-Graves County Ballpark, shall be fined not less than $250.00, nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each [day] during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 13-03, § 1, 9-8-03; Ord. No. 18-17, § 1, 5-8-17) 
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT AND PARKING VIOLATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - IMPOUNDMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4-12, § 1, adopted April 9, 2012, repealed §§ 16-50-16-56 in their entirety and added a new §§ 16-50 and 16-51. Formerly §§ 16-50-16-56 pertained to registration and licensing of motor vehicles and were derived from Ord. of 7-11-60, §§ 1-3 and 5-7; Ord. of 8-28-78, § 2A; Ord. of 2-25-80, § 11; Ord. No. 3-88, § 1, 4-11-88; and Ord. No. 7-92, § II, 3-13-92. 

Sec. 16-50. - Impoundment-Charges for towing, handling and storage-Hearing on validity of impoundment-Appeal. 
(a)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, the city may impound a motor vehicle parked, stopped or standing upon a street or public way within its jurisdiction in violation of an ordinance or statute prohibiting parking, stopping or standing in the location, manner or at the time the vehicle is cited or for any other lawful reason. 
(b)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, in addition to the fines levied for the parking or traffic offense, the city shall impose reasonable towing, handling and storage charges upon any vehicle that is impounded pursuant to subsection (a). In addition to the towing fees, the city shall charge an administrative holding fee of 30 percent of the towing costs, plus any preliminary sale advertising expenses, and a storage fee of $25.00 per day for the first 14 days and $15.00 per day for each day thereafter for each vehicle until redeemed. In the event the condition of the vehicle or circumstances of the tow requires the employment of extraordinary services or equipment, the reasonable charges of the towing operator, as approved by the impoundment/parking office, for such shall be added to the fee. 
(c)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, the release of an impounded vehicle shall be conditioned upon the payment of the towing, handling and storage charges imposed thereon, unless the owner or other person entitled to possession challenges the validity of the impoundment pursuant to subsection (d) of this section. A vehicle may be released to the owner or other person entitled to possession only upon proof of ownership or right to possession and proof of current, valid insurance. The city may require reasonable security, bond or other assurances of indemnification from a person who is not the registered owner of the vehicle prior to releasing the vehicle to such person. 
(d)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, the owner or other person entitled to possession may challenge the validity of such impoundment and request in writing a hearing before the hearing board created under section 16-70 by filing such request with the city clerk within the timeframe provided by section 16-62. The hearing shall be conducted within ten business days of the date of the request, unless the owner or other person entitled to possession waives the limitation or the city shows good cause for such delay. The city, or its contracted agents who have possession of the vehicle, shall retain possession of the vehicle pending the hearing, unless the owner or other person claiming right of possession posts a bond in an amount equal to the fines and fees accrued as of the date of the hearing request, or $75.00 whichever is less. If the owner or person claiming possession of the vehicle is unable to pay the amount of the bond, the hearing shall be held within 72 hours of the date the request for hearing is received, unless such person requests or agrees to a continuance. 
(e)  [Hearings.] 
(1)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, not less than five days prior to the date set for the hearing, the city shall notify the person requesting the hearing of the date, time and place of the hearing. In the case of a hearing required to be held within 72 hours of the date of the request as provided in subsection (d), the person requesting the hearing shall be informed at the time of his request, or as soon thereafter as is practicable, of the date and time of the hearing. 
(2)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, any person who refuses or, except for good cause, fails to appear at the time and place set for the hearing shall be deemed to have conceded on his and the owner's behalf the validity of the impoundment. 
(3)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, at the hearing, after consideration of the evidence, the hearing board shall determine whether the impoundment was valid and reasonable. Where it has not been established that the impoundment was justified, an order releasing the vehicle shall be entered. All fines and fees paid or amounts posted as bond because of the impoundment of the vehicle shall be returned. Where it has been established that the impoundment was justified, the hearing board shall uphold the impoundment and condition the release of the vehicle upon payment of all fines and fees accruing thereto. If bond has been posted as security for release of the vehicle, said bond shall be forfeited to the city. Any fines or fees in excess of the amount of the bond posted shall be ordered to be paid by the owner of the vehicle to the city. The hearing board shall furnish the owner or person appearing on the owner's behalf with a copy of its order. 
(4)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, the hearing board may consider a parking citation and any other written report made under oath by the issuing officer in lieu of the officer's personal appearance at the hearing. 
(5)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, an appeal from the hearing board's determination may be made to the Graves District Court within seven days of the hearing board's determination. The appeal shall be initiated by the filing of a complaint and a copy of the hearing board's order in the same manner as any civil action. The action shall be tried de novo and the burden shall be on the city to establish that impoundment was justified. If the court finds that the impoundment was justified, the owner shall be ordered to pay all fees and fines accruing as of the date of judgment. If the court finds that the impoundment was not justified, the city shall be ordered to release the vehicle, if applicable, and to return all fines and fees paid as a result of the impoundment and the plaintiff shall be authorized to recover his costs. 
(6)  Pursuant to KRS 82.625, the judgment of the district court may be appealed to the circuit court in accordance with the rules of civil procedure. 
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 2, 4-9-12) 
Sec. 16-51. - Impoundment-Vehicle abandonment, escheat provisions, and lien for parking violations. 
(a)  Pursuant to KRS 82.635, the city shall possess a lien on a motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this section for all fines, penalties, and towing, handling and storage charges and fees imposed thereon and such lien shall be superior to and have priority over all other liens thereon. 
(b)  [Impoundment.] 
(1)  Pursuant to KRS 82.630, if within ten business days of impoundment a motor vehicle impounded by the city has not been claimed, or a hearing has not been requested pursuant to section 16-72 and KRS 82.625, notice shall be mailed by certified mail to the registered owner, if known, and lienholders of record, if any, affording the parties the right within ten days from the date of notice to claim the vehicle or request a hearing pursuant to section 16-72 and KRS 82.625. The notice shall state that, if no hearing is requested, the vehicle shall be deemed abandoned unless the charges thereon are paid within 45 days of receipt of notice. 
(2)  Pursuant to KRS 82.630, after 45 days from the date of notice required by subsection (1) of this section an impounded motor vehicle shall be deemed abandoned and the vehicle shall escheat to the city. 
(3)  Pursuant to KRS 82.630, if the vehicle is judged suitable for use, the city may obtain a certificate of registration and ownership from the county clerk pursuant to KRS 186.020 and either use the vehicle for governmental purposes or sell the vehicle at public auction to the highest bidder. If the vehicle is not suitable for use, it may be sold for its scrap or junk value. 
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 3, 4-9-12) 
Secs. 16-52-16-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NOTICE AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 16-60. - Notice of illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this city or by state law, the police officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information available which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to the vehicle a notice or citation in writing on a form provided by the city, for the driver to answer to the charge against him at a place and at a time designated therein. 
    Such notice shall include the information set forth in KRS 82.610. 
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 4, 4-9-12) 
Sec. 16-61. - Penalties for parking violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation charged with any of the following parking violations shall be assessed a find in the following amount: 
Blocking an alley, driveway, or street. $30.00 Double parking. 30.00 Failure to display a valid, unexpired registration and/or vehicle license plate. 30.00 Improper parking. 30.00 Obstructing traffic. 30.00 Overtime parking. 20.00 Parking in a loading zone. 30.00 Parking in a prohibited area. 30.00 Parking within 15 feet of a fire plug or parking in a fire lane. 30.00 Unauthorized parking in a designated handicapped parking area. 100.00  
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 5, 4-9-12) 
Sec. 16-62. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-63. - Notice of violation. 
    Pursuant to KRS 82.615, any person who receives notice of a parking violation shall, within seven days of the date of the notice, either pay the fine set forth in the notice, or request a hearing as set forth in § 16-72. If the owner of a vehicle cited for a parking violation has not responded to such notice within seven days the city shall send a second notice by certified mail to the last known address of the registered owner of the vehicle as listed on the certificate of title. The city may assess the actual costs of the certified mailing and return receipt against the registered owner of the vehicle. Such notice shall state that if the owner of the vehicle does not respond to the notice by either paying the fine or by requesting in writing a hearing, within seven days of the receipt of the notice, the owner shall be deemed to have waived his/her right to a hearing and the determination that a violation was committed shall be considered final. Any person who fails to request a hearing or pay the fine within the seven days shall be deemed to have refused to pay the fine levied by the citation. The registered owner of a vehicle at the time the violation occurred shall be liable for all fines, fees and penalties which he has refused to pay. 
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 6, 4-9-12) 
Secs. 16-64-16-69. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HEARINGS 

Sec. 16-70. - Hearing board. 
    Pursuant to KRS 82.600 there is hereby created a hearing board empowered to conduct hearings for violations of this chapter. The hearing board shall be composed of not less than one and not more than three persons appointed by the mayor by executive order for a term of two years and who may likewise be removed at will by executive order. The hearing board may appoint one or more hearing officers to conduct hearings. Any action of such hearing officer shall be deemed to be the action of the hearing board. 
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 7, 4-9-12) 
Sec. 16-71. - Enforcement officer. 
    There is hereby created an impoundment/parking code enforcement officer who shall be authorized to issue citations under this chapter. This position may be a compensated or uncompensated position. In addition city code enforcement officers and sworn city police officers shall also have enforcement powers for this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4-12, § 8, 4-9-12) 
Sec. 16-72. - Contest of violation determination-Hearing-Appeal. 
(a)  Any person cited for a parking violation under this chapter may contest the determination that a violation occurred by requesting in writing a hearing before the hearing board. Such hearing shall be held no later than 14 days from the date of receipt of the request, unless prior to the hearing the person requesting such hearing requests an extension of time not to exceed 14 days. No less than seven days prior to the date set for the hearing, the hearing board shall notify the registered owner of the vehicle of the date, time and place of the hearing. Any person requesting a hearing who fails to appear at the time and place set for the hearing shall be deemed to have refused to pay the fine levied by the citation, and shall not have any further rights to appeal. 
(b)  At the hearing, after consideration of the evidence, the hearing board shall determine whether a violation was committed. Where it has not been established that the violation was committed, an order dismissing the citation shall be entered. Where it has been established that a violation was committed, the hearing board shall uphold the citation and order the owner to pay the citation within seven days.
